150202438.review: A short, cute game that is a nice showcase for VR. You take control of a little mouse, named Quill, as she navigates through environments that are reminiscent of human ones (mines, gardens, castles) but are cutely scaled down to mouse sized. Meanwhile, you use your controller to manipulate the environment to help her out. The gameplay is mostly simple environmental puzzles with some simple combat that can admittedly be annoying but is not anything too taxing or stressful. The game is short and fairly easy but it looks great with some nice environments and lighting, but where it really shines is Quill's animation. She's super expressive and it really adds a lot of charm to the game. Recommended.

150198918.review:
A short and rather basic platformer-puzzler with simplistic combat. It has strong [I]Trine[/I] energy, but is not as compelling. Play [I]Moss[/I] for the amazing visual design, but keep your expectations low for just about everything else. This is the unfortunate situation of state-of-the-art in VR gaming.

Note that this is just half of the game. You will need to buy [I]Moss: Book II[/I] to get a complete experience. Consider if that's worth the cost for you.

[I]Moss[/I] tells its story as a fairy tale read out loud to a child from a book. This conceit is a bit charming but is elaborated ad nauseam. The cut scenes are way too long, and generally narration throughout the game mimics an adult "doing the voices" for a kid before bedtime, instead of having characters speak as themselves and having a distinct personality. This tedious format is made worse by an incoherent, plodding story, lackluster writing, and humdrum voice acting. Something about heroes and treasure and villains and saving the world. I honestly couldn't even summarize it to you. It's like a Pixar film we pretend didn't exist.

However, the visual presentation makes these clichés worthwhile. For one, the level design is very well tuned to both VR technology and the story's subject matter. It's designed as if you're looking into a doll house, and of course it kinda is one: a world for tiny animals. It's simply wonderful to peer into this miniature universe, to stand up and look above and behind walls and corners for secrets and details. Though the textures and lighting are very simple compared to AAA productions, the understated cartoonish qualty is immersive and suitable. I especially appreciate the excellent character and monster animations. Because the writing drains the characters of life, the animation must do the heavy lifting, and it does so well enough. The protagonist is adorable and the highlight of the game.

So how does it play? It starts slow and trivial, but does become more engaging later on, with a few moderately challenging puzzles and combat situations, especially in [I]Chapter II[/I]. It's all .. fine. Unfortunately, controls for the many 3D platforming situations won't orient quite as you think they should and so it's too easy to fall and die. Luckily for that, the price of death is low in [I]Moss[/I]. It's all quite casual.

Should you buy it? First, consider that you will likely also buy [I]Moss: Book II[/I]. Both games provide a wonderful showcase for VR gaming. They're otherwise not so exciting.

143047389.review: Well this was just an adorable action/adventure/visual novel game.  The game is all done through seated VR play and you help guide your little mouse friend through the areas on a quest to defeat evil.  Some of the controls on the Vive weren't super clear at first and took a little experimenting to figure out, like pressing left on the right touch pad swings the sword or uses a switch and pressing right on right touch pad jumps.  Combat isn't too hard, though it's definitely more challenging later on in the game.  Combat generally takes place in "combat arenas" where the exits will be blocked by flames until you clear out the enemies or in rare instances, trigger whatever switch needs to be triggered.  The ability of the player to semi-control 1 enemy is an interesting mechanic and also leads to some nice puzzles.  The puzzles in the game aren't all that difficult to figure out and are largely environmental things like moving platforms around for your mouse friend.  There was one puzzle room near the end that I got stuck in briefly until I figured out that things just need to be done in a very specific order, otherwise there weren't any show stoppers that require looking up a guide at any point in the game.  There's lots of secret scrolls hidden throughout the levels for completionists to hunt around for, I haven't found all of them as of this review, though I'm likely to give at least one more try to see if I can find the rest.  The voice acting for the story narrator is good and fits the theme well.  The full game took me just under 4 hours to finish a run with what looked like maybe 75-80% of the hidden scrolls located.  It's definitely worth a look if you like adventure games with some action.  I'll be getting the second game in this series at some point to see how things continue.

We need more 3D Platformers in VR.

It has such smooth animations, great art design/scale, fairly well-designed levels/puzzles, and just a general level of polish that I haven't seen in the few other games of this desolate VR genre.

All-in-all, playing a 3D Platformer in VR is incredible. Moss is a damn good start to a hopefully prolific genre.

Moss is one of those VR games where you ask yourself: Why aren't more developers developing games like this? This is [i]brilliant![/i]

Most VR games have YOU be the protagonist of the video game (which VR is almost tailor made for, of course), but in Moss, you are NOT the main protagonist, but merely an observer of the story unfolding before you. You are what's known as a "Reader", and you embody this ethereal creature that watches the story of the little mouse Quill unfold before your eyes. You control Quill with your controllers, and she can do the basic running and jumping, climbing walls, attacking and dodging that you're used to from most platforming games. But what Moss does in addition to this is that YOU can influence the scene and help Quill by physically interacting with the world around her, and aid in her quest, like moving platforms that would be too large for a small mouse to move, or imbue her sword with magic, or heal her if her health is low. You can also take control of certain enemies if they become too dangerous for Quill to handle, and lead them elsewhere so Quill can reposition or heal.

[b]The story[/b] of Quill is a simple one, but it's very well told, and told in a very unique way, something I haven't really seen anywhere else before, which probably makes it stand out so much in my mind. Quill's uncle has been captured by the villains of the story and taken to a faraway castle, and it is up to Quill to go and save him with the aid of the "reader" and a few other colorful characters along the way. You will face many mechanical enemies that look like beetles, and go through various mouse-sized catacombs, mines, and villages on your way.

The only nitpick I have about the game would probably be the length of the game. It is not very long and can be completed in a handful of hours, even if you go full completionist and want to find all the secret collectibles. But again, it's mostly a nitpick, because if the only "bad" thing you can say about something is that you want [i]more[/i] of it, then is it really a bad thing?

Performance-wise there were a few areas where my machine started to stutter uncontrollably, but this was fixed by lowering the graphics quality from High to Medium. That being said, I have one of the best CPUs and GPUs on the market, so something like that shouldn't really happen.

But overall, I give Moss a high recommendation.

Moss es el claro ejemplo de que la VR también funciona en otros géneros más allá de la primera persona. El juego dura unas 5 horas máximo, por lo que pese a que no es muy largo, tampoco es una "experiencia Vr". Es decir, es un juego hecho y derecho. Hay que decir que el juego realmente se juega sentado (de hecho es el único videojuego VR que he jugado sentado), fundamentalmente porque es la altura correcta para ver los escenarios "correctamente", si jugamos de pies veremos los escenarios desde un ángulo "incómodo" y tendríamos que jugar mirando hacia abajo. No obstante, el juego nos invitará a menudo a levantarnos e inspeccionar los escenarios y verlos desde otro ángulo.
En el juego interpretamos a un lector de un libro, una especie de cuento de hadas cual "Historia Interminable", cuyos protagonistas son una ratona llamada Quill (aunque a mí me suena a nombre masculino XD) que encuentra un cristal mágico mediante el cual "ve" a una especie de ente ancestral, el cual encarnamos nosotros y es desde el punto de vista que el jugador verá el juego.
Con el Stick izquierdo controlaremos a Quill, con los botones derechos del mando de Rift S golpearemos con la espada y saltaremos para las plataformas, finalmente con los sensores de movimiento interactuaremos con Quill en diferentes situaciones de la aventura. Hay que decir que aunque el juego es impresionante de principio a fin, la interactuación con Quill la esperaba mayor. Es decir, el juego realmente si quisiesen hacerle en plano sin controles de VR realmente sería fácil de portear, pues lo que son las características de control de la realidad virtual tampoco es que se usen en exceso, eso sí, sería muchísimo menos impresionante el juego.

Los gráficos como ocurre siempre con la VR, visto desde el visor, parece literalmente otro juego, da igual las fotos y videos que veáis del juego... cuando os ponéis el visor no tiene nada que ver, una maravilla.

En definitiva, si sois usuarios de VR, o tenéis pensado pasaros a esta tecnología en un futuro, este juego es IMPRESCINDIBLE. A ver si la 2º parte (llamada Book 2) sale pronto en PC, porque es de los mejores juegos que hay para la VR.

115154034.review:
Moss VR is originally a Playstation title developed by Polyarc and the game was released in 2018. Moss is a VR puzzle adventure platformer but unlike most of VR games it is played from a third person perspective - which turns out to be your own perspective.

The game starts with you reading a book introducing you a fairy tale like story, eventually taking you into the story itself. Moss is a fully narrated story that makes you part of it. You play as Quill, a cute little mouse, full of enthusiasm. She finds a shard that calls a human sized ghost-like masked creature, a guardian angel of sort. This being is also you. You watch over Quill as she goes on her journey to save her uncle and the kingdom from an evil fire-breathing serpent.

Moss is a simple game that requires a bit of platforming. You control Quill and walk her through beautifully crafted environments that are joy to look at. The environments are single scenes and you have to walk from the place you appeared to the other end of the environment. Sometimes you can just freely walk through but mostly you have to solve an environmental puzzle to get to the other side. These get more and more complex as you progress and they require the intervention of you as the guardian. In the later stages of the game they can also span several 'scenes' and not just one.

You control Quill with joystick and buttons to jump and attack like in a traditional game. The guardian though has 'hands' - blue orbs. Those are where your motion controllers are so you can reach with them and physically move objects around, stall enemies, drag them around. You can also pet the mouse on the head, high-five her when she presents a hand or heal her when she takes damage by holding her for a while. You can even spook her if you wish to. It truly feels like you are a magical being doing magic.

There is some combat but it is fairly simple. At first you just hack at the enemies but later on you will find you that you can stall enemies, move them around (so they explode elsewhere), you can even shoot with the enemies you currently hold in your blue-orb hand. In some areas of the game there will be big fights requiring you to multitask a bit with both of your hands while still moving Quill around (stalling an enemy while controlling Quill and attacking the held enemy for example). This most probably is not necessary but adds more depth to the game and to me it felt natural.

Moss is a game that is about immersion and they did an excellent job at that. The game proves that in order to be immersed in a game you don't need a first person view. The environments are rich and beautiful and I spent a lot of time just looking around and waiting for things to happen. I was so curious that I also spend some time walking around and peeking around every corner. This way I also found out that there are hidden items you can collect (scrolls) that are often somewhere where they are either hard to reach or they are hidden if you are just sitting in the middle of the scene.

The sound is also excellent. There is everything you'd expect and the sound is also 3d. The sound effects are well chosen and they seem to be real be it a turning of a heavy page from the story book at the beginning, Quill's squeaks or her steps. You will hear background noises perfectly matching the environments (or not because it will feel so natural). Stop and listen to the sounds. You will discover how well the sound was done.

Verdict: Moss is a game that provides a unique experience that only VR can deliver. Moss is one of the most immersive games I played even when the game is played from a third perspective. The gameplay is on the simple side but it also means that the Moss is a great game to introduce people to VR and gaming in general. The only downside is that the game is rather short. You can finish the game in 3 hours and be little bit disappointed in how suddenly it ends. If you enjoyed this game and crave for more there is a sequel already out for Playstation VR and soon to be released for Quest.

111466587.review:
[h1]“The greatest adventure is what lies ahead.
Today and tomorrow are yet to be said.
The chances, the changes are all yours to make.
The mold of your life is in your hands to break~ 🎶”
~[i]Jules Bass, The Ballad of The Hobbit[/i][/h1]

Do you like fairy tales as much as I do? Seriously, in my opinion, the one just can't be too old for a good fairy tale. Exactly the opposite. We all need one from time to time. And that's, ladies and gentlemen, is exactly what we've got here. A carefully crafted fairy tale made with a lot of love. Which is... kinda surprising. I mean, even though [b]Moss[/b] is [b]Polyarc, Inc.[/b]'s very first game, the guys are far from being amateurs. Exactly the opposite. [b]Polyarc[/b] is a small team that started with some ex-[b]BUNGiE[/b] employees. [b]Moss[/b] is a child of [b]Richard Lico[/b], who's known for [b]3D[/b] models he made for games like [b]HALO 3: ODST[/b], [b]HALO: Reach[/b] and [b]Destiny[/b] series. Talking about [b]Destiny[/b], by the way. A lot of [b]Destiny[/b] guys here. [b]Chris Alderson[/b], [b]Mike Jensen[/b], [b]Corinne Scrivens[/b], [b]James Yavorsky[/b], [b]Stephen Hodde[/b], [b]Tam Armstrong[/b], [b]Danny Bulla[/b], [b]Tam Armstrong[/b], [b]Brendan Walker[/b]... They're all here. Graphic designers, [b]3D[/b] artists, sound designers, programmers...

Don't expect [b]Moss[/b] to be anything like [b]Destiny[/b], though. Or like any other [b]BUNGiE[/b] title out there. Like I said, [b]Moss[/b] is a fairy tale. Remember when [b]Ron Gilbert[/b] and [b]Shelley Day[/b] quit [b]LucasArts[/b] to start telling kids their own stories in games like [b]Putt-Putt[/b], [b]Pajama Sam[/b] and the others? That's pretty much what we have here. Some big guys quit [b]BUNGiE[/b] to tell us a fairy tale. While controlling a young mouse called [b]Quill[/b], we should face a lot of dangers in order to save our uncle. And the atmosphere-wise? It's brilliant. Imagine [b]Hanna-Barbera[/b]'s [b]Once Upon a Forest[/b] mixed with the prologue part from [b]Nintendo[/b]'s [b]The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past[/b] and a slight aftertaste of [b]Majora's Mask[/b]. That's pretty much how [b]Moss[/b] feels. Sure, there isn't much going on in this game, but the attention to details? It's absolutely fantastic. [b]Quill[/b] is an [i]incredibly[/i] cute character and thanks to how she's perfectly animated... No, seriously, she's so cute you'll want to hug her. Wait... you actually can! Thanks to how [b]Moss[/b] is a proper [b]VR[/b] title, you can actually pet [b]Quill[/b], give her high fives and so on. [i]Cuteness overload![/i]

But of course, it isn't just about [b]Quill[/b]. I don't know about you, but personally, I always had a very special place in my heart for stories about tiny creatures in the big world. Books, cartoons, video games... Everything – from [b]Astrid Lindgren[/b]'s [b]Nils Karlsson Pyssling[/b] to [b]Honey, I Shrunk the Kids[/b], [b]Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers[/b] and [b]Pikmin[/b]. I love it all. And [b]Moss[/b]? It captures that certain atmosphere perfectly. I didn't mention [b]Once Upon a Forest[/b] for nothing. [b]Moss[/b] is a game about unlikely little hero in a big world full of dangers. For me? It's more than enough to enjoy this game. But honestly, the good things don't end here.

Every level in this game is like a tiny little diorama that comes with a puzzle to solve and a secret or two. Reminds me a little bit of [b]Captain Toad: Treasure Tracker[/b]. I mean, even though gameplay-wise, [b]Moss[/b] is (way) closer to what we had in [b]CAPCOM[/b]'s [b]Zack & Wiki: Quest for Barbaros' Treasure[/b], every screen here looks like a handmade diorama you're free to explore. Doesn't sound that special and technically, it isn't (especially levels here are really, [i]really[/i] tiny), but as usual, [b]VR[/b] makes everything better. See, [b]VR[/b] here isn't only about juicy [b]3D[/b] with particles and stuff. In this game, you'll be able to look at diorama-like levels from different angles. And it's a very nice touch, since from time to time, you'll actually [i]need[/i] to change the angle, since some things here will be hidden behind the others.

Don't expect [b]Moss[/b] to be too hard or complicated, though. Technically, it's even more simple than [b]Zack & Wiki[/b]. It's a very basic game that the entire family will be able to enjoy. It's pretty short too. Well, not [i]too[/i] short (four hours of gameplay is not really [i]that[/i] bad for [b]$29.99 VR[/b] title), but still, it's short and the latest update that added some sort of a hidden levels that you can access by finding secret entrances, doesn't really help much. My biggest complain, though, is the fact that... this game ends with the cliffhanger. Sure, [b]Polyarc[/b] are already working on the next chapter (you can easily find its trailer on [b]YouTube[/b]), but honestly, “to be continued in the next game” is not... what I like seeing in [b]$29.99[/b] game that doesn't even have “Episode I” in its title. Doesn't look fair to me. Especially since there's no [b]100%[/b] guarantee that the sequel won't end up being a lifetime [b]PlayStation[/b] exclusive (I'm not trying to say that there's something wrong with the exclusives, but buying yet another helmet just to be able to learn about how things end is not... really a good idea). I can deal with the short game, but at least, give me a proper finale, will you?

And still, [b]Moss[/b] is a beautiful game. And while it's far from being the most complicated [b]VR[/b] experience I ever had (the entire game is just that – a set of cute, yet basic puzzles, mixed with some [b]Zelda[/b]-like battles), it's sure one of the cutest ones. Probably [i]the[/i] cutest one. That certain feeling I had when I saw [b]Link[/b] waking up at stormy night, hearing [b]Princess Zelda[/b] calling for him, asking him to save her from evil [b]Agahnim[/b], who trapped her in the castle's dungeon? That certain feeling is totally here, in this game. [b]Moss[/b] is cute, [b]Moss[/b] is charming and all in all, [b]Moss[/b] is, like, a perfect fairy tale for the entire family.

[b]P.S.[/b] A couple of technical details. [b]Steam[/b] version of the game supports three different headsets – [b]Oculus Rift[/b], [b]HTC Vive[/b] and [b]Valve Index[/b]. [i]But[/i] if, like yours truly, you have [b]HTC Vive[/b], you're out of luck. Don't get me wrong, though. The game will work totally fine and you'll still be able to enjoy it, [i]but[/i] it looks like controls here were made for something more gamepad-like. Which means that [b]Oculis Rift[/b] and [b]Valve Index[/b] with their sticks would probably feel way better. It's not like [b]Moss[/b] is unplayable with [b]HTC Vive[/b] controllers, but... you know how it is. Those feel a bit messy in this game and you'll have a little bit more problems than needed with some achievements. Like the one that requires you to do things without dying. Again, it's impossible to die in this game completely (you have infinite tries and therefore can die as many times as you want), so, messy controls won't affect your playthrough [i]that[/i] much, but as long as you have a choice – go for something with sticks.

This game is also fully integrated into [b]SteamVR[/b] environment and finishing it will award you with a cute little [b]Quill[/b] prop. Personally, I love such stuff. Always thought that it deserved more attention. I mean, come on, [b]Valve[/b]! [b]SteamVR[/b] desperately needs an update! With more props, better [b]UI[/b] and more showcases! One way or another, though, since I think I can call myself a fan, I was really glad to put [b]Quill[/b] statue on my virtual shelf. Thanks for giving this game a proper treatment on [b]PC[/b], [b]Polyarc[/b]! Can't wait for a sequel.

First time I tried this game I was a bit skeptic and did not get hooked, it looked too simple and boring.
Second time I tried it I played for a bit longer and really liked it. It just starts slowly and gently.

Moss is a fixed-screen puzzle-platformer VR game where you get to control and interact with a little mouse called Quill. The player is the "reader", and is part of the game storytelling (ie you are a kind spirit for the little mouse). This is cleverly done, as when you are playing you are "in" the game, and when switching to cutscenes you are set back to the "real world", where you are reading the story that is happening, similar to how it is done in The Neverending Story. There is no speech (except for the narrator's, that reads the book), but the mouse use gestures.

The level of polish and overall attention to detail in this game are high, which is a rare feat in VR games.
While the platforming and puzzles are nothing too special (they just do the job, they are simple puzzles satisfyingly adapted to VR controls) the environments however are pure marvel. Moss is a game where where mostly everything is mice-scaled, like a dollhouse, and it looks gorgeous. The graphics are about the best I have seen in a VR game.

This is a short game (~4h) with little repetition, so I wish it was longer ! It ends a bit abruptly.
The devs were planning for a sequel, which hopefully has been confirmed not long ago.

Played using a Rift S, with in-game graphics setting set to high, and ODT Pixels Per Display Pixel Override set to 1.6.

Moss is easily one of the best vr experiences that I've played so far. It has a wonderful storybook aesthetic, a delightful main character, and breathtaking visuals, like my god do some of the shots look good (I'm getting ahead of myself. Put a pin in that for me if you don't mind.) Moss takes advantage of the strengths vr has while minimizing its disadvantages. For example, vr makes some people sick because of the locomotion, so there is no locomotion, the main character Quill does the moving for you. The game is a 3D puzzle platformer, a genre in which the biggest problem is a lack of depth perception, but that problem is solved by being in vr. Could it have been a screen game? Sure, I bet it would still be great, but here's the biggest advantage that vr has that Moss uses to it's fullest: The sense of scale. (remember that pin? we're just gonna pull that out.) Good lord, are the visuals of this game friggin' breathtaking. You start out in a forest, then go into a village with cute little houses going up the trees, and it really feels like something these mouse people would build and live in. Then you're reminded of the size when there's just a deer getting some water right in front of you. It doesn't even notice Quill, just slurping up some bog water. and finally, there's the castle, good lord the castle. It's hard to describe, because you can tell humans are too small to live in it, but it still just towers over you. Honestly, if you're immersed in this world, -and you will be- seeing that castle up close in the final chapter is something that rivals the citadel in Half life Alyx in a way that's hard to describe. I could go on and on about the visual splendor this game has, but seriously, if you own a vr headset, get this game now and see what I'm talking about. you won't regret it.

Ps. I didn't get to the charm and character the game has, but just play and be sure to give Quill a lil' high five. You'll get it then.

This game looks simply amazing. The screenshots do not do it justice - you have to see it from a headset.

Visuals are crisp when they need to be, and the lighting is amazing. And the animations... Oh boy, did they blow their whole budget on that?

The game has a number entertaining (and sometimes challenging) puzzles, and an engaging though simple story. It is, however, short, at only several hours in length, even with digging through for secrets. The narrative seems like more of a prologue or first act than a complete story, however, hinting at more to come.

Gameplay is, for the most part, great, though perhaps somewhat simple overall due to the short length of the game. As someone else said, there are a few small upgrades to equipment, but aside from unlocking one new ability, they don't seem to do much other than change appearance.

Controls are for the most part, good, though it can be difficult to tell which direction the mouse will head from the get-go when you start moving, and this also changes somewhat with the direction your headset is facing. I fell off a lot of ledges and missed a lot of jumps due to this. Aside from this, this is how third-person VR should be done!

There are some performance issues. You will need a good video card (I'm using a 1650 Super which is... Acceptable. 72 fps usually.) to run this reasonably, and in longer sessions the game can accrue some sort of problem that causes performance to tank (a quick reboot fixes this, but it makes it annoying to stream). I ran it originally from HDD, but found performance was a lot better from SSD (less stutters), despite the fact that the game is small enough to fit in my RAM...

Unique gameplay, amazing visuals, good implementation, decent story - but short in length. Grab it if it's on sale!

100387655.review:
*Played on a Quest 2 linked to my PC*

Moss is astonishing.  A tour de force, that would not be possible outside of VR.  

You control a little mouse named Quill, and yourself, the "Reader".  Each "page" of the book you are reading is a "screen" in the game.  Its like a little diorama and you have to get from one end to the other.  Sometimes this entails sword fighting, sometimes puzzle solving, sometimes running for you life.  Each scene is crafted down to the smallest detail and is gorgeous.  You will frequently interact with the scenery, moving platforms so they are close enough for quill to jump on and things of that nature.  The puzzles and fighting are all fun and challenging, without ever becoming tiresome.  

The bond between yourself and Quill is acknowledged, and is part of the story.  There is also a voice that narrates the events.  It all serves to draw you in deeper to the game.  There are times Quill will turn around awaiting a high five from you, you see "your" reflection in still pools of water, the game is great at making you feel "there".  I cannot stress how much the tiny little crafted environments help in this, looking around and running around with Quill is incredibly cool (a la Mario 64 back in its day).

My complaints with Moss are few and far between.  The only one being I wish there was more of it.  I clocked in at about 4 hours and felt like I took my time even in certain parts.  I estimate I got around 75%+ of the hidden scrolls in my 4 hours.  I feel like between now and the sequel, I will be going back and getting the ones I missed, Moss is so good, and is worth it.  

So many VR games try and push the envelope of what is possible and/or want you to have a massive space to be able to play in.  I wish more games were like Moss instead.  Taking traditional game concepts and putting them in VR space and adding gameplay and visuals that only VR would allow.  Another example of this, sadly Playstation exclusive, is Astro Bot Rescue Mission.  Games like this are some of my favorite VR experiences and I find them astonishing.  I eagerly await Moss 2.  

9/10

99524654.review:
Really quite a lovely game, albeit with a few frustrating bits. (Note: Requires VR; seated OK.)

The environments, world-building and story are very well done. Backgrounds, skyboxes and incidental animations really sell the sense of place and scale. There's a bit early on with a deer that drives home "small mouse, scary world" vulnerability in a way that would only really work in VR. There's a lot of worthy detail to savor beyond what's actually required to progress in the game.

Movement controls and exploration are fine for the most part.  In a few places, combat turns into a pat-your-head-and-rub-your-tummy cluster-caress, as you try to control Quill with the thumb-stick and buttons on one controller while you wrangle a mob or shove a physics item with the other.

The explore-y and puzzle-y bits were what I really enjoyed about Moss. Any time I was under time pressure or dealing with non-trivial numbers of enemies, I enjoyed a lot less.

There was one particular bit I thought was a huge difficulty spike, when actually the problem was that the thing I was trying to do was far harder than what the game was actually asking me to do. (There's a room with four weak enemies with projectile attacks. I killed one, it respawned, and I concluded "oh, they repawn infinitely; guess I have to do a jumping puzzle while dodging bullet spam". In reality, each one respawns once. Kill each twice to thin them out, then do the jumpy bits at your leisure.) That's arguably my own fault for making a bad assumption, but on the other hand there are plenty of enemies in this game that do respawn forever...

Moss is somewhat unusual in being a third-person VR game. This works surprisingly well (and the fourth-wall-breaking conceit they use to explain it away works smoothly enough that it isn't distracting). But there are some bit of the game where you -- you, the player, in the real world -- will need to achieve some of the more advanced yoga poses in order to see where you're going or spot some hidden object. This is sometimes used as a deliberate part of level design, where something is placed in a way that would be obvious to the character in the game but is hidden from the player unless they undergo a specific set of contortions. Not a deal-killer for me, but may be hard to swallow depending on your setup and how limber you're feeling that day.

There is some Metroidvania-style backtracking, where you'll find a barrier that's initially impassible, then acquire some plot coupon and return to place you've already visited to do something you previously couldn't. This isn't bad in and of itself, but the game doesn't really tutorialize it very well; I found myself briefly stuck until I realized it was that kind of game.

I played through this in about 5 hours, playing at a leisurely pace, looking for collectibles and doing side quests. It's a bit short, but it's as long as it needs to be to do what it's trying to do. It feels finished, without overstaying its welcome or getting repetitive.

In summary: Not a flawless or life-changing game, but amusing enough to recommend without reservation. Some good novel uses of VR, and some stunning visual settings. If they do the sequel threatened by the cliffhanger ending in this one, I'll probably buy it day one.

Brilliant game. Best VR experience so far. 

The gameplay is a lot like a Legend of Zelda game, where you control a jumping, climbing, sword swinging protagonist through a series of environmental puzzles. The big difference is that you're *in* the environment. They're all panoramic. You'll sometimes need to move and lean to get a better look at things. Most of the puzzles are solved by manipulating the environment with motion controls, and then navigating your little mouse friend through them.

The storybook sequences are slow, and definitely drag the momentum of the game down, but don't get turned off by that at the beginning. Think of them like exposition screens during loading sequences.

Moss is a fantastic game for people new to VR. It's a seated experience, there's no jump scares or motion sickness issues. The controls are intuitive. It's a great way to experience VR for the first time.

90459198.review:
TL;DR: Moss is a platform game where you control AND interact with Quill, a little mouse, in a mission to save her uncle. If you ever played Herobound on Gear VR you know what to expect gameplay-wise.

The game is GORGEOUS, the screenshots or Youtube videos doesn't make it justice. The VR gives you a presence in the world, you can look behind walls and other obstacles, move some of the objects, heal and give power to Quill and even control some of the enemies to use their capabilities against their peers. 
It's 10000x times better than Lucky's Tales where VR was only a gimmick, here it really makes sense, sorry for pancake players. 

Gameplay is similar to Legend of Zelda i.e. a mix of platforms, puzzles and combat. 
The combat itself is very simple as you can basically jump, attack and dodge. You are able to take control of enemies to block them in place allowing Quill to hit them without danger. You can also use their cannon or make them explose to kill other enemies or help you solve some of the puzzles. 
The puzzles are quite simple, it's often a mix of moving an object in the correct position, step on a pressure plate or hit a distant crystal to lower/raise a platform. You'll have to use the enemies at your advantage to trigger the pressure plates or hit a crystal while Quill stands on the platform.
The platforms sections aren't too difficult except in the last portion of the game where you need to quickly jump from platform to platform while a giant snake is throwing fireballs at yourself. I didn't really experience moments where I was jumping in the void because of a bad perspective.

Length-wise I spent around 4h for a first walktrough and 2h30 for consequent replays. You can redo each stage to collect the dust or relics you missed. 

For achievements hunters: there is an achievement where you need to complete the game from a new save without dying once. It looks feasible when you redo each chapter independently but the difficulty reside in doing it in one setting without having upgraded armor or weapon. There is no built-in exit game button so you need to use the SteamVR "Quit game" option when you're about to die, fortunately the dying sequence is quite long.

Yes. The game is short. Go in with that knowledge, and you will not be disappointed. For the price of two movie tickets and popcorn though you get a 4.5-5 hour experience that, unlike so many movies you'll watch, you won't soon forget. I'm a 40 year old dude and some of my favorite games involve very large guns and/or visits to blood-soaked hells, which is why when I say that there are some moments in this game that are "so pretty I almost cried", I hope you  take it seriously. Look, if you're so broke that $30 is a serious consideration, and you need entertainment that'll last you, pass on by. More likely, if you own a VR system $30 isn't much - and the experience here is worth it. The sense of scale, the attention to detail, all top notch. 

If you have a Quest and - since there is no crossbuy - you are wondering which version to get, 100% get it on PC VR (if your PC is up to it). Its a sit-down game anyway so the mobility of the Quest get you little, and the advanced use of lighting and materials here means that its likely a much degraded experience on Quest. The only reason I'd pick it up on mobile is if you want to take it and share it with others. Note: while there are some collectibles you might want to go back for, its otherwise a very linear game. I've played this for a couple of hours and it's a lovely game so far. It's a puzzle-platformer, (I'm old, so I'm going to compare it to Abe's Oddysee).

It's the first game that I got for my Quest 2 and it works fine with Steam and with my Link cable. I'm happy with this because it's like being in one of those old Mario games, only in real 3D, and because it's a gentle introduction to VR. I get motion-sickness, and I've stocked up on Meclizine, but I haven't really needed to take it for Moss.

I've rounded out my VR library with Obduction, No Man's Sky, Asgard's Wrath, Tokyo Chronos, and Half Life: Alyx. I'm certain that any one of those, with the exception of Tokyo Chronos, is going to be a little harder to get used to than Moss.

To sum up, the graphics are wonderfully vibrant, the music and sound is very nice, the voice acting is great, I'm enjoying the puzzles and I get a sense of accomplishment when I finish one. There was a part just today where I solved a difficult puzzle and the mouse looked up at me and smiled and waited there until I reached out my hand and gave her a high-five.

Definitely recommended. : )

Edit: I got ny a couple of screens each morning for another week or two and just finished Moss. The visuals in the last third of the game were even nicer than in the first two-thirds, and you wouldn't think that beating the last boss of a puzzle game could get your blood flowing like an action game, but it really does here.

Again, very happy that this was my first VR experience.

Moss is a 3D platformer, with some fights too. The environment which you see will clearly be a 3D one, in which you can lean around. I didn’t try to actually move around, the game is supposed to be played standing (or seated, but for that you will need an arms length of clearance around your chair). You are viewing from an elevated vantage point the current set-piece / room, in which your mouse, Quill, will act. You control her movement with the left thumbstick. The buttons on the right controllers are for the jump and for the attack/interaction. However there are some elements with which only you can interact (like a water wheel, which you can stop by grabbing it). Eventually you will meet enemies, which you must fight through. Some puzzles require you to use the enemies. You can grab them, and herd them toward certain push-down platforms, where they will keep pushing it down till you move them away. Later, when you meet shooting enemies, sometimes you must take control of them and shoot specific actuators, to proceed on. This shooting is done with the right thumbstick, and was fairly imprecise for me. You might ask : But what happens if I kill such an enemy with Quill, will I fail that segment? Well, if an enemy is required to pass forward, they will keep respawning indefinitely. Which lead to some confusing situations for me, as there is another mechanism : fighting through several waves of respawning enemies. At first I thought that those enemies will respawn indefinitely, and I must progress through somehow among them. It took me some time to figure out that when a red force field blocks an exit, I must kill all the respawning enemies. Most of the time you can take your time to progress through the platforming, but towards the very end of the game there will be severe time limits, so you must progress continuously, with little room for error.

The version on Steam is actually the game of the year version, it will contain the DLC content too. This DLC content is meshed in with the playthrough. You can access it at three points, where some green sparkling is visible. Interacting with that green sparkling will open a green portal, which will take you to a central hub, from where 3 different explorable areas will be accessible, unlocked by the gate by which you entered from in the main world (I think). Once you complete such an area, you will have to leave through the green gate you always arrive through, and you will be continuing the main story line. As such, it is entirely possible to skip one or all of these DLC contents. If you unlock all three, at the end of the final area there will be a boss fight.

As for the platforming, the possible positions of interaction are marked with white color, similar to what is present in Tomb Raider (2013). It also means that if something is not marked as white, you will probably have no way to scale it, even if it seems entirely plausible. Quills jump distance is quite short, which can be a problem when you want to jump across moving elements. Also it is very hard to aim precisely with the charged up sword in the DLC. I think there are some unmarked spots, if you stand on them than her precision will increase greatly (sort of location triggered aim assistance). But since they are not highlighted, even if they exists, it is hard to use them.

The graphics of the game is nice. However your experience will be affected more pronounced by the actual type of VR headset you are using, than for a normal game played on different monitors. There isn’t such a wild disparity between different monitors than between different headsets. In particular, mine had a pronounced optical distortion at the outer 50% of its field of view, a problem not present for monitors. Also I had to play with reduced resolution, as my GTX 1070 was clearly at the low end of the VR capable video cards. I was planning to buy a 3000 series card to replace it, but things didn’t turned out in such a way.

All the narration will be done by a single person, Quill will merely issue some squeaking noises (but even those are done by the same voice actor). If you get stuck, often Quill will pantomime some hints, like pointing in a direction, or mimicking shooting if you are supposed to control a shooter to interact with some triggers. The game might have music, but I was completely oblivious of it.

It might appear as a casual/chill game, but some fights were very frustrating for me, like the boss fight at the end of the DLC, but I got problems with regular fights too. To add to my frustration, sometimes my left thumbstick seemed to be left stuck, making Quill to keep walking in the left direction. Since it was my first VR game, I’m not sure whether the problem was with my controller, or in the game. It happened randomly, so it was not like my controller was always wrong. This is why I think it might have been a problem with the game. Also, the menu button wasn’t mapped to any button on my controllers. I had to map it through Steam, and I added it to the left grip button. I think accessing the menu is entirely optional. The main reason for that would be to see your progress for some collectibles, and later to replay a specific chapter, probably to collect everything. There are two kind of collectibles : scrolls, which unlock a picture, and dust, which you gather by smashing barrels and similar objects. I gathered around 80% of the collectibles, but due to the annoying fights/triggers, I don’t intend to replay the chapters to gather the rest. When I wanted to exit the game, I just selected exit for it from the Steam dashbord.

You will play through room size environments, and you are not required to move around. If there is an object with which you must interact, it will be within an arm lengths distance. The game can be played only with VR controllers, there are no options for gamepad. I think entering a room will autosave your progress. There certainly wasn’t a manual save option, only an option to switch between different save slots (if several people would play the game, I guess). Also while in a set, there might be several internal checkpoints. Reaching these are not saved when you exit the game, however if you fail, you will restart from these internal checkpoints and not from the very beginning of the level. As for the length of the game, it took me a bit above 6 hours. It certainly didn’t felt short for me. Some further time went with the mapping of the menu button, and after finishing the game, I replayed the first chapter for some collectibles, that I was not aware the first time that they were as such. The game reaches a closure, but the developers chose to twist the ending with a declaration for further progress through a sequel, making it seem unfinished. But without that turn of events, it would have ended properly.

The game run without crashes for me, but even with a reduced resolution it wasn’t maintaining all the time a constant 90Hz. But I was playing on a mere i5-2500 and GTX 1070.

What do you get with Moss?  For starters, bang for your buck.  The game is short, sure, but full of content and lots of fun to explore.  The art style is gorgeous, and the worlds and characters created in it are wonderful.  I found myself stopping in every single level just to look around at stuff.  It feels like you are playing with a dollhouse or some sorta miniature landscape.  You often have to physically move around in the level to see where to send Quill, which gives you opportunities to see all the cool things you'd otherwise miss in a flatscreen game.  There's so much detail to each level, but it's not overwhelming or distracting.  But let me talk about the animation, because it's what really makes this game pop.  The animations put into Quills movement and body language give so much life to her that I would often feel worried for her safety, or remorseful if I caused her to “die”.  Not only that, but she interacts with you in many ways.  You can sneak up behind her and startle her, you can give her a high five, you can pet her, and all the while it feels very immersive with the way she moves. 10/10 on world and character visuals for sure.

The mechanics are mostly good, very intuitive and a lot of fun.  I will say that while a lot of the gameplay is easy, jumping some gaps requires almost perfect timing as they are spaced in a way that doesn't provide much room for error.  The fighting mechanics are very easy and simple, but still lots of fun regardless.  I do feel like it gets a bit wooden after a short while, but I couldn't say what might fix that.  The puzzle mechanics are probably the best part.  They really found a good way to make VR work for puzzles.  You use your hands to interact with various objects, sometimes while simultaneously controlling Quill which can be tricky but fun.  And you really have to move your head around to see where she is at and where to send her.  They got really creative with using both VR and traditional controls to make for a very satisfying game.  8/10 for controls and mechanics.  
 
The narration/voice acting and story reminds me of getting bedtime stories read to you by a parent or older sibling.  I will admit it's a little cheesy, but it fits the childish fantasy world plenty fine.   It's not a huge part of the game, though, as most of the time spent is in silence as you figure out puzzles.  I would love to see them expand on this story, however, whether making a continuation or perhaps introducing more characters.  7/10.

I can't finish up this review without touching on the music.  Jason Graves, the composer, did music for such games as Dead Space, Tomb Raider, And Until Dawn.  I know for the majority of people, music is something that just fills the silence.  But in Moss, they really did put a lot of work into the music.  It doesn't just sound good on its own, it does a good job of fitting the entire art style.  The music feels very magical and mysterious, similar to Jeremy Soule's Morrowind soundtrack, but also has some Russell Shaw's Fable vibes, too.  Excellent, 10/10.

Moss is absolutely fantastic. Before playing this game, I was honestly skeptical of what VR could add to a third person platformer, or indeed third person games in general. Turns out the answer is: a surprising amount. The ability to literally stick your face into a level and look around makes figuring out the puzzles and finding collectibles a joy, and it really helps immerse you in the world of Moss. There's no character movement, as the game is presented as essentially a series of dioramas like the pages of its titular book, so that cuts out one of VR's biggest hitches without feeling like anything is missing.

The plot and setting of Moss are honestly fairly rote - a big scary badness awakens in a whimsical world of tiny folk, and you have to rescue someone from it. What makes the game special is the love poured into it, especially the protagonist Quill. Her movements and vocalisations are incredibly expressive, her animations are flawless, and the game allows you to interact with her directly - high fives, mussing up her fur, waving to each other. It really helps to sell you on the notion that this is a tiny little person you're helping out, not just a player model.

The controls are great, the setting is great, the audio is great, Polyarc really made something special in Moss. If I had to criticise, $40 CAD is quite a bit to be charging for a game that's about 3-4 hours long depending on how completionist you're being. [h1]Remarkably detailed and heart-meltingly cute VR platformer[/h1]

I don't often write reviews for games I haven't finished or sunk a large amount of time into. However - Moss was one of the first VR games I picked up while I'm waiting for a GPU upgrade for more graphically intense games. I picked up Moss in the [i]Wonder of VR[/i] collection with other fun puzzle games to tinker around in while I wait. From the first few minutes, however, I found that this game is much better than I anticipated.

[b]One of the important talking points for VR is "sense of scale"[/b] - It's often in the context of grand landscapes and huge impressive monoliths that make you feel small. You may be looking at this game and thinking a 3D platformer where you control a mouse wouldn't be a game that really highlights this. However in Moss, I believe it's just as important and just as impressive. You're floating above incredibly intricate and detailed miniature environments that make you feel like you're watching actual little animals running around. It's remarkable, and most importantly, adorable. [b]Seriously, I can't get over how cute this game is.[/b]

[b]I may be biased[/b] - I love miniature things in real life, such as model railroads or tabletop war games - This game is that same thing, but full of life and motion. I also loved [i]Redwall[/i] books as a kid, and this game really taps into that type of world.

[b]The gameplay is a classic puzzle platformer[/b] - It's mildly challenging and never frustrating. Controls are simple and solid. The gameplay itself isn't particularly innovative, but it's polished and enjoyable.

[b]Don't judge a book by its cover[/b] - If you're looking at the screenshots and think "Meh, it just looks like an average 3D platformer", just wait into you see that little mouse for the first time with your headset on. You get sucked into the world almost instantly. Highly highly recommended for both seasoned gamers and curious people experiencing VR for the first time.

85260923.review:
This is part of my script from a video I created. You can either read the script here, or listen to it on YouTube.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4djuUoNJn7E&ab_channel=ThisKory99

If you don't want to click links, search "ThisKory99" on YouTube and you'll find it.

Moss is a Platform Puzzle game which has you controlling a little mouse named Quill, while simultaneously using your hands to interact with various objects within its beautifully crafted world. Nothing compares to a platformer in VR, especially one like Moss.

The way the story is told is something I would have never imagined. You are in a large cathedral hall with a book in front of you, and you are known to Quill as "The Reader". Upon opening the book, there are pieces of the story narrated to you, and then you enter the book itself to work directly with Quill and share the story with her. It's a beautiful way to tell a story, and in the middle of each chapter it takes you out of Quill's world and back into the cathedral to continue the storytelling from a different perspective. During this time, you notice that day suddenly turned to night, and it gives you a sense of actually becoming so immersed in a book, that you lost track of time, and completely immersed yourself in the story of the book to the point where you were no longer focused on your surrounding (those surroundings being the cathedral hall). This is something which happens to us when we are deep into the story of any book we read... we get lost in the visions of our imagination, and forget about the world in front of us. I can't begin to express how amazing this feels, and it's something I wish I could experience every time I read a book.

Without spoilers, the story is simple, and the primary objective is to make your way to a castle to find your uncle. Throughout your journey, you fight various enemies, complete challenging environmental puzzles, and gain a few new powers as your progress through the 4 hour story campaign. And Quill can’t do this all on her own, so she needs you there to help her during her travels.

Quill is the most charming character I’ve ever seen in a game. I actually looked up the most charming video game characters on The Google, but I only saw fake articles, which all had false information, because Quill wasn't on any of the lists I found. Quill is definitely in my top 3 most charming video game characters, next to Prince Sidon from BOTW, and Dorian from Dragon Age: Inquisition. Quill has such a great personality, and she really shows a lot with her body language. You can see Quill express her fear, sadness, excitement, and joy. And when you complete more challenging puzzles and fights, she rewards you with a high five, and an adorable dance, which gets better and better as your progress through the story.
 
The environments are amazing, and I was always excited to see what was next. Each scene has its charm, and every one of them is beautifully crafted, with plenty of variation to keep you entranced throughout Quills journey. 

Moss shines not only in the beauty which each environment brings. But the ambient sounds are absolutely breath taking, and gave me chills when hearing owls, frogs, and crickets in the night, and every environment has its own unique sound... Not only are you already immersed in VR visually, but Moss does an absolutely amazing job with their audio design. Everything from the sound of Quill’s sword hitting enemies, pots, and boxes, to the sounds of blades of grass shuffling around as Quill runs through them all brings you deeper into immersion with the world.

The soundtrack isn’t on the same level as Ori & the Blind Forest, but it definitely has its moments. and I have to say, Morla Gorrondona, who narrated the entire story did an amazing job, and really sells the fantasy storybook feel.

The controls are simple, and if you’ve played any 3D platform games before, then you’ll be very familiar with the controls with Moss. On the Index Controls – and other controllers are very similar I’m sure -, the left thumb stick is to control the direction of the little one. You use the A button on the right controller to jump, and B will swing your sword. Pressing B once will give a single swing, and pressing B 3 times quickly will have Quill perform a large sweeping attack, and this varries depending on which weapon you are using. If you attack once or twice, you have the opportunity to quickly dodge by pressing the A button quickly after attacking. Whichever direction your left thumb stick is facing at the time, will be the direction which little quill will make her dodge towards. The A button while not attacking will be used for jumping and pulling yourself up ledges or dropping from them. 

This is where the controls get fun. With your triggers on either controller, you can interact with the environment more directly. You are able to heal Quill by pulling the trigger over her body and pulling away to lift her up. Enemies can be manipulated by holding the trigger over them, and there are other various interactions such as opening doors and assisting with puzzles. You can also light torches and break boxes for dust.

Speaking of dust, there are 2 types of collectibles in the game which earn you achievements. Sparkly dust can be collected by breaking boxes, pots, and other various objects either with Quill’s sword, or you can do this yourself with your hands and the right trigger on the controller. The second collectible is mosaic fragments which create an image when you collect them all. Some of the mosaic fragments can be challenging to find, so make sure to look through each scene thoroughly, otherwise, this will give you an excuse to play through the story again to collect all of the pieces.

So, let's get into the heart of the gameplay. Puzzles. At first, the puzzles are simple, and Quill herself can overcome most puzzles on her own. But later on, you need to work together with Quill, both with puzzles and in combat. You may be asking yourself how you are not already working together with Quill when you are controlling her movement and attacks. Well, you have two hands - which look like blue orbs in the game - which are able to move through the world which Quill lives in, and you are able to manipulate enemies and work with her to complete puzzles, as mentioned earlier.
	
The way which this is introduced to you is perfect, and it starts slowly, with it gradually building up to intense combat sequences where you must defend Quill by manipulating enemies around her, while she is attacking her own set of enemies. Keep in mind, when I mention Quill and yourself, you are controlling both.
	
In one combat scenario I was using my left controller thumb stick to control Quill's direction, and using A and B on the right controller to jump, dodge, and attack, all while using both hands to reach out in front and to the sides of me to manipulate enemies using the trigger on both controllers, all to assist Quill while she (myself) attacks a single enemy without becoming bombarded by the others. 

Of course, you will never experience this kind of combat technique in any flat-screen Platformer, and what the developers of Moss did is absolutely incredible, mind blowing, and makes me want to cry all at the same time. I say it makes me want to cry (and I did, several times) because I have never experienced something so satisfying in gaming until now. The interactions you have with Quill are perfect, and I couldn't ask for any more.

The puzzles are designed brilliantly. There were definitely a couple which I had a tough time on, but with a little more thought, I was able to complete them. If you are having a tough time, Quill will notify you of your objective with a pointed finger, which I thought was brilliant.

In Moss you effectively play as two separate characters. You play as Quill (the mouse) as a third-person action puzzle platformer, and also as a first-person VR character where you have to interact with the world. This leads to some really fun puzzles where you have to do both at the same time. The combat as Quill is simplistic, just an attack and a dodge, but works well for the game. The story is good, it tries to fell like a fairy tale and achieves that quite well.

Visually, I think the game looks quite good. I'm sure part of it is because you aren't close to the models and textures, but I thought the environments looked pretty regardless. I also really loved Quill, the model and animations are very well done.

I only really had 2 problems with Moss.
First, it's not very long. It's not really shorter than Budget Cuts or Vertigo (which I also beat in a similar amount of time), but I would have liked it to be longer, like 8-10 would be great.
Second, the ending wasn't too great. It basically just said the game is just the beginning of the story and there is going to be a sequel. It's not a big deal (the game was fine by itself) but I would have rather the game was a complete story, or just hint there could be more without being so blatant that this isn't the complete story by itself. Again, not a big deal, but it sorta bugs me.

Overall, this is easily in my top 10 VR games. I would recommend everyone with VR play this, especially because it's a seated game so it's easy to get into.

Enchanting!

Moss is a storybook adventure with an impressive sense of scale. It feels like catching a glimpse of a miniature world normally hidden away from prying eyes, while the "normal size" world also sprawls out around and above. 

Never did I feel more enthralled by the idea of sitting in cold and muddy swamp water, just to watch protagonist Quill going her way to solve puzzles and occasionally fight enemies with my active help. Since I'm also in direct control of her, there's only one person to blame when she accidentally jumps over a cliff (I AM SO SORRY QUILL!). 

She's aware of the player's presence, gently nudges towards puzzle solutions through expressive animations and sounds alone and - my heart - at times even offers a high five after a problem got solved. That's sunshine after a cold and rainy day.

Graphics, sound, music and fairytale story play perfectly into this unfortunately so far unique mix. Before I bore you with this review though, I'd like to conclude it with something I said several times during my ongoing playthrough.

"Woah! This is SO cool!"

More of it, please!

Moss is a must have for VR users and while it doesn't do the most with VR itself, it will captivate you with it's satisfying gameplay and charming tone.

In the world of Moss you control two characters, "the reader" which is your viewpoint you see who can interact with environments and a cute mouse named Quill, who's actions are controlled by the inputs on your VR controllers. Quill knows of your existence (you're a floating mask in the sky) and will often face you to cheer when the both of you accomplish a certain task, dance, ask for high fives or speak to you with sign language. Even though you control her directly these little moments are wonderful and make Quill feel like a real partner, you'll be happy to oblige and give her all of the high fives she wants. 90% of the gameplay is platforming with Quill and combat (it's simple, but it's satisfying!) and running about, but as The Reader, you'll be moving platforms for Quill to progress, taking control of enemies and later on you'll be charging up Quill's Sword so she can fire blue fireballs that explode.

The visuals and sound are whimsical, you're plunged right into a fantasy world that's soothing to take in and explore, it feels alive and filled with magic. The developer was not afraid to use bright colors to paint these landscapes, everything is just a sight to behold and not just in the immediate playspace, but also in the far distance. There's a lot of beautiful vistas that you'll want to just stand up and stare off into. While the visuals aren't the most high fidelity thing you've ever seen that astonished me the most were the animations, everything is so well animated and fluid, it's AAA quality. The sound compliments all this well with music that sounds appropriate for a fantasy title, it's great.

Story isn't the most important thing in Moss, it's basic but it works well. It doesn't try to convolute things by making things overly pithy with tons of made-up words that fantasy tends to do; but you won't be playing Moss for the story anyway.

As a VR title, no it's not the most deep when it comes to gameplay and the VR interactions are the most basic of "move this, pull that" that you've seen in every early VR tech demo, but all of the components are put together so well it's quite impressive. Definitely give Moss a shot!

Moss is a wonderfully beautiful and adorable game.  As of review, I played through the story twice because of how much I enjoyed it, and I'm still playing to try to get the full run with no deaths achievement.  So far, Moss is my favorite VR game, for a number of reasons:
- It’s so gorgeous, the sights and sounds are a pure delight to take in.
- There is no motion sickness because the perspective is always fixed and it's meant to be played sitting down.  
- The concept of being a tree spirit helping Quill, an adorable mouse, is just so heart-warming and seeing your reflection is such a cool moment.  I did not anticipate I would become invested in the story.
- The gameplay is really fun and has a lot of room for you to play the way you want to play.  You control a sword-wielding mouse and you, as a tree spirit, have god-like powers to assist in battle and solve puzzles.   I've seen comparisons to Legend of Zelda, and in terms of gameplay, that is very accurate.
There are some flaws that I have to mention:
- The controls can be a real pain sometimes.  For the most part the controls are fine, but sometimes Quill won’t do what you want her to do.  I’m pretty sure that the joystick follows the orientation of your head, rather than your hand – as a result, sometimes it’s hard to get Quill to do what you want her to do; like she might not know if you want to pull yourself up a ledge or move to the side and aiming with a Scorcher is comedically hard.  After playing a while, I got used to it, but when I watched my friend play for the first time, she gave up in less than 10 minutes because she was having trouble controlling Quill.
- You have to restart the game to change the seating orientation, it’s not a big deal, but the position that you open the game in is the position that you play the game in, so if you need to change the position, it requires a restart of the game.

Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone with a VR headset.  It is beautiful and engaging, the length is tight (it doesn't overstay its welcome), and keeps calling me back for more.  I can't wait for the sequel, I hope there are many more Moss games to come.

Moss is a VR-only puzzle-platformer that’ll charm your socks off. The story is framed around reading a book you’re physically pulled into, following which you become connected with the timid but responsibility-bound mouse Quill and adventure awaits the both of you. Although in typical platforming fashion you are directly in control of Quill your presence is regarded by the cast as a sidekick!

While this may be first title released under the Polyarc name it’s obvious that these devs are talented industry veterans. Firstly, the audio direction is brilliantly immersive with layered and detailed environmental sound effects backed by a subtle and whimsical soundtrack, it makes the whole forest feel like it’s teeming with life.

That veteran talent is also on display in the visual design, the dioramic environments have been put together with a careful thoughtfulness about how the scale will feel in 3D. It’d usually be easy to forget you’re watching over a tiny mouse, but looking up at the towering trees and wildlife puts the world in perspective. Textures are well detailed and there’s no clear compromise to visual quality despite the performance requirements of VR. With such strong audio, graphics and characterisation you will find Moss’s world absolutely engrossing.

So, full marks so far, what about the gameplay? Well, that’s a little more of a mixed bag. Moss definitely shows that platforming makes a great fit for VR, gaps have a physicality making jump judgements trivial. Using motion controls to spin and adjust platforms makes you feel powerful in contrast to tiny Quill and moving your actual head to look around the environments in search of hidden collectables is immersive like nothing else.

The tough pill to swallow in all this is the short 3-4 hour runtime and lack of replayability. Once you know the puzzle solutions and plot points Moss doesn’t hold the same magic anymore. I also reckon there may be more innovative VR platformers on the horizon as on reflection the gameplay is a little by the book. Hopefully Polyarc take the all-but-confirmed Moss 2 as a chance to flex their creative muscles and make something with a strong gameplay identity to go alongside their captivating one-of-a-kind world.

68244999.review:
In Moss you are the reader of an interactive fairytale book about a cute little mouse named Quill. 
In practical terms this means you’re playing a fixed camera 3rd person platform puzzler with a dash of combat. Quill is controlled via the traditional gamepad inputs on your controllers, but as the reader you also have the power to manipulate certain objects in the world with your VR motion controllers. 

Since this game was developed for the PS4's Sixaxis controller, you're sadly left with glowing orbs instead of hands, and very rudimentary interactions with the game objects.

While the story is beautifully conveyed through the wonderful visual artwork, some of the actual gameplay elements weren't quite as impressive. The platforming mechanics felt a bit stiff and unpolished, while the combat was too simplistic and barebones to be really engaging. Being able to hold and control some of Quill's foes with your "hands" while fighting them keeps it from getting too trivial though.

Luckily the meat of the game is in the puzzles, and they were for the most part enjoyable to solve, but as mentioned, more complex motion controller interactions with the world objects could've given the puzzles some extra depth.

On the technical side, it's sad to see that the devs haven't bothered fixing the performance issues when using any other graphics option than "LOW", which therefore has been chosen as the default. Judging by several threads on forums and reddit, you will not be able to maintain full framerate regardless of your PC specs if you go above that.

Overall a short (< 5 hours), visually great VR experience with very enjoyable puzzles, but mediocre platforming and combat.

79%

67244519.review:
Beautiful and creative game. It's like the Legend of Zelda (one of my all-time faves), except Link is an adorable female mouse named Quill. The player controls Quill's movements, but you play as the hero's companion--Not Navi, but useful like Midna, except you're about human-sized and look like the No-Face guy from Spirited Away. I loved everything about this game except the controls.

PROBLEM:
The controls were too awful to be able to enjoy this game at first. The Vive controllers just don't have enough distinct button inputs for 3rd person VR games, and the trackpads are so difficult to use while blindfolded, especially if you have smaller hands. Quill's 2 main actions (attack and jump) are set as the left and right side of one trackpad button by default. These 2 distinctly different actions require frequent, unforgiving precision in order to progress through an adventure platformer, yet they are each mapped to one half of the same physical button, which has no tactile markings of any kind to indicate which action you are about to trigger before you do. It was entirely too easy to accidentally roll your thumb across the bottom edge of the pad when trying press one side or the other, which of course registers as the wrong action at least 50% of the time. You can see how this would be a problem when you're trying to perform a series of precise platform jumps across a bottomless chasm (miss one jump and you have to start over!) or when you are trying to attack multiple waves of enemies (3 hits kills you and have to start over!).

SOLUTION:
I would still recommend buying this game because you can adjust the game's controller bindings in your Vive settings so that it's actually playable. I mapped the "attack/interact" action to the right trigger and the "jump" action to the left trigger. That made them distinctly separate inputs that are easily pressed on purpose and not easily pressed on accident. I set the Reader's "grab" action as the side grip buttons, which is easy enough to squeeze quickly for a charge attack, although physically harder to hold down if you have smaller hands (but at least it's contextually appropriate for what it does in the game). The side grip might be easier to press accidentally if you're holding the controller tightly during a moment of tension, but it won't hurt anything if you do.

To Polyarc:
I hope you still end up releasing Book 2, because this game was great. I recommend patching it with alternative control options (see above suggestion about the triggers, also options for Index Knuckles if you haven't already!) so that new players aren't discouraged from playing Book 1 and getting excited about the sequel themselves.

To Valve:
Please give players more options for controllers. The Vive controllers are gigantic, so if you have smaller hands (as most women do), you're constantly shifting the controller around trying to comfortably reach all the buttons, and the side grip buttons are a literal pain to use. Developers shouldn't be discouraged from creating unique and interesting games like Moss, which needs better input options. The Nintendo Switch has like a half dozen controller options for every type of game or any size of hand, and the entire system costs way less than a VR setup. I got this from Humble Bundle and never played it before, didn't seem that interesting. Boy, was I wrong big time! One of the best "real" VR games I've played.

+It is almost like a Zelda game. You move through dungeons, fight enemies, solve puzzles and jump on platforms to progress. Occasionally you open chests to get new equipment and items, in a very Zelda like way.

+No hand holding. The game never tells you what you need to do or where to go, you are on your own to figure it out.

+You control the character, a mouse, with buttons as any game, but simultaneously you use VR controls to interact with the game world, like puzzles and harass enemies. You can also high five the mouse!

+For some reason none of the product page videos or pictures show what the game looks like when playing. 
You sit down and the game world opens in front of you, like if you are a giant watching over the character you are playing. Occasionally you will need to get your ass up, look around the area to figure out how to proceed and find hidden collectables. I think this was really cool.

+The sceneries and animations look fantastic! 

There are some downsides
-Short. About 3-4 hours, a little more if you want to replay to find all collectables.
-Trackpad controls are not very good on Vive. Occasionally I had troubles lining up my jumps, then died because the jump button didn't register.
-Some controls were not explained very well in game and caused frustration.
-Price. For me it would be hard to justify the normal 25e price for such a short game.

[i]Played with WMR[/i]

Moss is an approachable, enchanting, captivating title in which you play as Quill, a small lovable rodent, who happens upon a special item that bonds her to the player. Thus, the two of you set out on her journey together. 

There are quite a few aspects that when combined together make the game fairly immersive and a rather special experience. This combination includes just how well-polished the art, animation, and environments are for a VR puzzle-platformer adventure game. Secondly, the unique small scale and perspective of the game. Both of these combined together to create some really adorable-looking mouse towns and a great sense of scale which adds to the feeling of an epic adventure. 

On top of this, the gameplay is stellar. Being able to use the joysticks on the WMR controllers really makes controlling Quill a blast. Furthermore, the simplicity of having only two action buttons, one for jump and one for attack, is super simple and rather elegant. Yet there is some additional complexity laid on top of this first layer of gameplay by adding on the spectator’s abilities. By having these two different types of characters to controls it pushes the player to use physical movement, which is the main way you control the spectator’s abilities, and Quill’s platforming abilities in conjunction with one another which leads some excellent puzzles and combat.

63342443.review:
VR needs more games like this where you feel like the play area is set out in a field in front of you statically, and you're managing it from overhead like a giant god.

It's like board games and video games had a baby.

Like a board game, everything has a physicality to it, like you're managing a table covered with small objects and you have all three dimensions to work with, but like a video game everything is alive with its own simulated behavior for you to experience.

I think this represents another genre in VR that needs more love. It's akin to the difference between 'first person' and 'third person' games for non-VR. The world has an overabundance of 'first person' equivalent games in VR because everyone is excited about the sense of presence you can get, but I think there's an equally exciting opportunity to make this style of game.

I would be interested to see a room-scale game that takes advantage of these principles, like you're standing in front of a table in VR, and on top of that table (AR style) is a pop-up game world that you're free to examine from all angles as you play. 'Tactics' RPGs, city management, god simulators, etc. would probably benefit immensely from this style as well.

I'm really excited about what Moss is pioneering here, and I'd recommend everyone give it a try.

But I will say if this wasn't an exciting VR game showcasing a new way to design games, it would actually be pretty mediocre. It's pretty short, and the swordplay and platforming don't feel remotely as responsive or cool as competitors in the Zelda-like genre. Also you don't get much of a sense of exploration or progression. It's very linear.
