61778844.review:
[i]Moss[/i] is a delight, and if you've got the VR equipment to play it, you absolutely must.

Set in a fantasy kingdom inhabited by mice, the player assumes the role of the Reader, a mythical entity, who must aid a young mouse named Quill in her quest to save her uncle and, quite possibly, the rest of the kingdom. Right out of the gate, the act of multitasking by controlling Quill [i]while[/i] reaching across the virtual space to manipulate the environment is as immersive as it sounds, aided in no small part by the presentation - the appearance of each level is like a small diorama laid out with nooks and crannies for the player and for Moss to poke around in. Each level represents a discrete platforming or puzzle challenge (or some combination thereof), with breaks for combat in-between, the combat itself often feeling like a puzzle of timing and prioritization. But progress is impossible without Quill and the Reader working in tandem; the effect is that the player feels like a partner on this journey, and it's hard not to form some small attachment to Quill not just through plot but through play, too. (It's something of a joke how excited people get when you can high-five Quill, but dang it, if it's isn't just as awesome as it's built up to be.)

That said, the [i]real[/i] star of the show is the presentation in [i]Moss[/i], which takes the bones of a serviceable puzzle platformer and transcends it to something else. The whole game is presented as a classic fairy tale, read from a large tome in what appears to be cathedral-like library. The game itself is to scale, meaning that trees and ancient ruins loom over the player and Quill, granted some mystique and awe in their physical enormity. A deer passing by in the background feels like some ancient forest spirit. Clockwork insects feel larger and more menacing. Shields and armors littered about an ancient battleground poke up out of the mud, eerie reminders of how large the world is in contrast to the game's tiny protagonist. What is, in effect, a small adventure, feels truly [i]fantastic[/i] through its set dressing. And, of course, that's to completely ignore the impact of the music, or the adorable squeaks and chirps of Quill herself.

There are some minor drawbacks, though writing this, they feel like quibbles. The platforming can occasionally get frustrating, with the level laid out in such a way that it's difficulty to gauge jumps; having said that, since it was technically my face that was the camera, I'm not sure if that's inconsistent design or just an embarrassing case of user error. The game is also quite short, clocking in (including the Twilight Garden DLC) is around 4 to 5 hours, not including a bit of extra treasure hunting for the completionists out there. It also, and I'll remain vague here, ends on a bit of an open note, suggesting either future DLCs or a sequel.

Quibbles aside though, [i]Moss[/i] is an excellent example of what you can do in VR. It's charming, fun, and shockingly engaging, right through to the end. I feel like it's a stepping stone, a bridge between contemporary design sensibilities and the more experimental end of VR, playing with what the medium can do when it moves away from first-person design. So, if you've got the time, give this faerie tale a go and go become friends with a mouse.

This game is really great. I've played Lucky's Tale, Chronos and Moss and as far as VR platformers go this is the best one of those three.

The use of motion controls is great, the puzzles are great and slowly ramp up in complexity. Most screens have a scroll as a bonus that you have to find and collect which adds replayability and keeps you engaged.

The combat seems fairly shallow at first but as it gets harder you will find yourself scrambling to use Quill at the same time as you use your hands to control enemies and interact with Quill. It becomes really hectic and an experience I have not experienced in gaming up until this point.

The story is enough to keep you going but the main character is what really sells it. Quill has a lot of personality for a little mouse and the interactions with the player adds a needed touch of feeling like you're really fighting alongside the protagonist.

The environments are absolutely packed full of detail too. I can't wait until we get higher resolution headsets to really appreciate the work put into the art.

Probably the best VR platformer at the time of writing this, Dec 2019.

51 Minutes in and all I do is say "wow" every few minutes. The levels, animation, sounds, narrator, storytelling, all is vibrant, lovely, cute and on point. It's definitely the best seated experience I had besides "I expect you to die", which is also great fun. It managed to drag me in quickly.

What is Moss? 

It's a seated experience and it mixes and blends different experiences, real world and gaming related, into a neat cute and lovable package. You sit and watch while Quill, the cute mouse you're bonding with (and control), walks around the diorama, almost like the way you played with toys as kids, with the hero toy having an adventure. Everything in front of you is the stage and it basically plays like a sidescroller with 3D levels instead. It rewards looking around (with your whole upper body) to find hidden scrolls scattered in each stage, sometimes out of your sight if you don't move. So keep looking around and help Quill collect them all. It's a plattformer with fights, puzzles and it just oozes charm.

The story, as far as I can tell, is neatly told, it's definitely a childrens book story, but don't let that fool you. It's a cute heroes journey and I'm ready to hop back into it anytime. 

Quills Animation is so cute and fluid, you'll find yourself wanting to pick her up and cuddle the little white furball. ♥

...

TLDR: If you're owning a VR, you should own Moss. It's cute, adorable, inspiring, beautiful game and a must buy for VR if you ask me. And if you can find it on sale, buy it twice. Just buy it.

Valve Index, GTX 1080, i7-6800k

This game is phenomenal,

The game seems to be a little bit inspired by the movie "The Neverending Story", since you're reading a story from a book, and playing the story.

In this game you can do two things :
- Control the mouse (the animal, not your whatever brand mouse) with the joystick of your controller, there are combats and puzzles to solve.
- Interact with elements in the world (like moving blocks etc.) to help the mouse progressing in this world. This is done in VR, you use your controller to select elements and drag it around (Since you're playing the reader of the story, you're basically breaking the 4th wall).

The mouse is cute and makes some cute little noises, even if he dies.

You don't need a big room to play this game, actually you're supposed to play it sitting on a chair, you don't need to move at all, but sometimes you need to lean forward to be able to reach some elements in the world, it's a top-down view game (which is not shown in the trailers), it you play it sitting on a chair it feels like playing a board game, so don't worry you probably won't get motion sick.

It works perfectly with the Valve Index, all displayed controls shows the Valve Index controller.

Framerates are good, it's not the most beautiful or detailed game, but it's still very beautiful, it uses the Unreal Engine 4.


Great game, I finished it after playing it for 5 hours, the story is not completed, this is just the story of Book number 1, but I hope there will be a second book.

Was hoping for Valve to finish their '3' VR Games or BL2 VR to be my first VR game. Played some free to play VR to get use to it with my new Index. But no Valve games (The Lab though is really good) and BL2 has a lot of problems for now. So got Transpose (which is fun and amazing graphics), but haven't finished it yet. Then decided to buy Moss. I'm so glad I did! The graphics and immersion is out of this world. 

You feel like you're in a actual diarama set within a real location that matches it. As you look around your play area the plant life, beach, logs, rocks, cliffs are really there.  One scene had a deer that seemed so real. I hate mice, but Quill is so darn cute you can't help but like her. She'll want you to give her high fives after beating a puzzle, try to get your attention at times,... 

Like said, you just don't move Quill around like it is a 3rd person view of yourself. You do controller Quill most of the the time, but there is still interaction and Quill 'realizing' you're there and interaction with you (the Reader). That make it feel like more than a game, but team work.  

The controls work for the most part, sometimes they just take getting use to, other times seems like a chore. But so far the best in VR have tried, except for maybe The Lab (valve). The developer does a pretty good job of leading you in the direction you need to go. But at times (like with lot of games) have to go check out a youtube video of some gameplay to figure out what to do. Also wish there was a way if you were quick enough to save Quill when she falls into water or off an edge, but there isn't.

So far, with my limited VR and using anything other than a keyboard/mouse, I LOVE this game. Going to be sad when it is over.  Pick it up!

Although there's something of a little difficulty hurdle to overcome with the touchpads, there are only a few scenes in the game where you really feel like you're being hobbled by them. Much of the difficulty comes not from the combat, but from the distinction between what edges are and are not climable/grabbable.
All too often you will hit the edge of a platform, pillar etc, and watch little quill slide off into the abyss below. The reason will almost certainly be because your thumb on the trackpad accidentally changed her direction mid-jump and cost you the distance you needed.

This is never more apparent when jumping between pillars consecutively, with each attempt taking the better part of a minute.

However, when you're not repeating the same series of jumps while leaning ever closer towards the platforms to focus on the movements of your mouse, this is an absolutely charming game. The art-style, the level design, the characters- every part of the execution draws you into this wonderful world where you are the floating eldritch giant mask, and before you is your stalwart mousy companion who you must guide, protect and cheer to victory.

In essence, a good game, on the premise that you don't get tilted easily.

TL;DR: I recommend this wholeheartedly if you are able to do some serious manual dexterity for the late game. Not so good if you really need to do the whole thing seated and your arms tire easily.

Cons:

I loved this game to start with, and was thrilled that I had found a VR puzzle game that was so well done. The puzzles are definitely designed from the ground up to be "physical", not just recycled from non-VR mechanics. The logic of them is consistent, and elements are introduced and built upon as you move through the game. Personally, I liked the "remember to look everywhere" aspect as well, as it encourages the player to really look at the scenery, not just speed through.

Unfortunately, I really do need games that I can sit in one place and not have too much demand for time-sensitive actions, and there is first a slow ramp up on the number of (autonomously) moving parts in the puzzles, then a very significant spike that I just wasn't able to manage. Based on YouTube Videos, the spike is pretty close to the end of the game, so I am wondering if this is an example of Dev Testing (people very familiar with the game being the primary testers due to time pressure, leading to an unintentional difficulty spike).

I am 5'2", and had to get up and take a step or two to reach certain game elements, because the play area exceeded what I could reach from a stationary position, and there is no way to scoot your avatar around except to physically walk. Given that the two modes listed are Seated and Standing, I found this disappointing. My VR area is not set up for this behavior.

I am aware, however, that my situation is unusual, so unless you are under similar constraints, I say grab it and enjoy. :-)

53414266.review:
Absolutely fantastic game. Well worth the sale price and I think this is a mandatory play for anyone with a VR headset.

The good:
Moss is a great game that displays a high amount of polish and delivers a very enjoyable VR experience. The combination of the music, level design and setting, novel interactions with characters and set-pieces, and absolutely adorable little mouse companion make this into one of my mandatory VR plays.

The concept of a top-down/platformer RPG in VR works far better than I expected. The experience of being inside highly detailed miniature worlds is an effect only capable in VR, and is a novel experience that doesn't lose its magic throughout the game and provides an entirely new way to build and solve puzzles. The disconnection from the body of the VR player from the game world lets animators deliver smooth animations that lend to a feeling of polish not found in many FPS titles that need to map models and animations to the players real-world body. This allows the decades of advancement in modeling, texturing, and animation, found in normal flat-screen gaming, to apply to a VR world without any of the jankyness found in IK rigs or other compromises in many VR titles. This creates an environment that creates a powerful sense of immersion. My wife, who's not a gamer at all, was able to fall in love and play this game for a solid 6 hours straight in a day. Completely unthinkable in any other title.

The concept of the Brothers Grimm-esqe fantasy, of a little mouse running through a fantasy medieval world is an excellent choice for the physical scale of the world. Levels are beautiful to look at, interacting with Quill is adorable, solving puzzles is engaging, and the music sets the atmosphere. My only real gripe is that I wish it was longer.

I hope this game sets a standard going forward, and we continue to see games in this genere progress, and its concepts brought over to eventual table-top games, RTS, and city-building games. 

The bad:
- Needs to be longer. There is a content update however, but the game is so much fun I don't want it to end.
- Lacks some depth of gameplay. The levels are well designed, the combat is fun, and there's the chest of weapon and skill upgrades throughout the game that reminds me of earlier Zelda titles. I do wish however that there was more stuff to find, more easter-eggs, more gear, harder boss fights, side-quests, mini-games or secondary skills, and more NPCs to talk to. The game is the main story-arc and that's it.
- Story is a bit shallow and predictable. It's bog standard fantasy, but feels too much like a derivative of a Brothers Grimm tale. 
- Needs a better on-boarding experience. No tips or tutorials, you just kinda have to figure out the controls for yourself, and the only controller tips that pop up at the beginning of the game are very low contrast and difficult to see.

From the beginning, you are thrown [i] literally [/i] into the story of moss as a reader, interacting with the world and to help your new found best friend Quill. With every puzzle solved, sometimes harder than others, Quill will give you a thumbs up and music will strike up this pride of being just smart enough. Stuck on a puzzle? Combat feels just as satisfying. Dashing and sword play is just fun and hoard sequences are great and also reward you with that closer bonding connection sitting and by the end of it. And, with the new update, you get to interact with Quill with regards to combat that feels even more intimate. [spoiler] You can eventually unlock a sword that you can touch and use to fire ranged projectiles. At this point Quill is practically channeling your power, and that connection becomes literal. [/spoiler]

In total, this game is part experience, part puzzle platformer, part mini sword fighter, and it makes you love every second of it. While replayability may be lacking as besides a few collectables you can find by replaying chapters, once you play the story, that's about it until they release the next chapter- that first run through... 49983599.review:
[h1]Played On: [b]HTC Vive[/b][/h1]

Moss is a third-person puzzle platformer for VR. In it, players take control of a small mouse named Quill who, armed with a sword and a lot of heart, will find herself battling, jumping, and climbing her way through several landscapes to save her uncle Argus. Though unlike other third-person VR games, you aren't just left as an unnamed entity floating in the void; you are known as The Reader, and you will find yourself working in tandem with Quill to help her on her quest. There's a fairly deep story that encompasses the past, present, and future of Quill's race, and while the game doesn't end on a cliffhanger it does leave room for another installment.

Much like Theseus, this release places the camera in a stagnant spot that allows for optimal viewing of the current location. Players that might find themselves prone to motion sickness will be pleased to know that there is no camera movement whatsoever; unlike Along Together, which finds the camera panning with the movement of the characters. Although Moss is a seated experience, I found that a handful of locations required me to stand up to see where to move Quill and how to pass certain areas, so those that are completely chair-bound may not be able to participate in this adventure; at least not without a guide or some guesstimation.

The only real downside to Moss are the controls. After spending just a little over an hour in the game, I'm finding that my hands are aching and cramped due to the convoluted layout and semi-faulty mechanics. Everything works pretty well so long as you're taking your time, but moving fast is of the essence the closer you get to the end of the game. Trying to maneuver Quill in a speedy manner causes many control-related deaths, as she doesn't seem to want to grab on to a ledge unless she jumps at it perfectly straight-on. Additionally, she seems to want to stop running and start walking if you hit the dead zones between directional inputs. Evading attacks is nearly pointless as well, as you must push left and then right to perform the slow technique.

What makes Moss so special isn't its graphics, which are decently life-like, or its amazing soundtrack, but the interaction between yourself and Quill. At the end of my playthrough, I found myself very attached to this little mouse, and I felt a real sense of sadness in my heart each time she died. A few times I found myself instinctively reaching out to try and catch her before she fell. This bond is started from the very beginning of the game, as Quill will even look at you as curiously as you look at her; we all do it, getting really close to certain models to try and inspect them as thoroughly as possible.

If you're looking for an extremely fun seated adventure, then Moss is definitely a worthwhile investment. The price isn't too steep, considering the campaign length is roughly 4-5 hours depending on how good or bad you are at platforming. There's also some replayability if you're interested in finding hidden collectibles. The real satisfaction in playing this game is the unique bond that you'll end up feeling with Quill by the end of it all; as you've high-fived, cheered, bickered, and otherwise interacted with each other for the entire event. Moss is another excellent example of how third-person games can, will, and do work in a VR environment.

I strongly recommend Moss, but with a caveat. Let's boil it down to the basics, then start with the positives:

Moss is a 3D platformer controlled from a side-on view. I used the Vive controller, and with this you steer the protagonist, a mouse called Quill, with the left trackpad, controlling jumps and swings of her sword with the right.

The positives:

The game is visually gorgeous. The presentation, where you lean into the game space like some small diorama unfolding below you, is very effective and quite unique, in my experience. It's worth getting just for its looks, in my opinion. The design of the levels hints of a larger world in the background (literally, in some  cases).

Quill is full of personality, interacting with the player's avatar (occasionally holding out for a high-five)

As for the player's avatar, you don't see yourself much, just the hovering, glowing globes of your 'hands', but you look like the cousin of No-Face from Spirited Away, which has to be a plus point.

OK, the downsides:

It's not super long. I played it for about 5 hours, and my playtime was probably extended because of:

THE CONTROLS.

Now, this is as much an issue with the Vive's controllers as with the game. The touchpads can degrade in functionality, and this is a game that needs them at peak responsiveness. Jumps and attacks can fail to register, though the alternate mode which uses the whole touchpad to jump and the menu button to attack, ameliorates this somewhat.

However, steering a character in 3D space using a touchpad with no real directional reference doesn't really work all that well, especially when trying to line up jumps.

For a controller that's so temperamental, jumps shouldn't need quite the pin-point accuracy demanded in this game. It's easy to miss a jump because your press missed, or you pressed early in the hope of getting it to register. You generally don't have to go far back to retry, but in a few cases you get put back at the beginning of a tense sequence. Frustration can build.

Even though I've spent most of this review complaining about the controls, I still recommend Moss.

My parents got me an Oculus for Christmas, and having heard all I have about Moss, I immediately downloaded it. My mom made fun of the "mouse looking for some cheese" game while I set it up, and then I got sick, leaving my mother to enjoy the Oculus in my stead. She proceeded to do the entire playthrough of "the mouse game" so this review is from her point of view.

PROS

• “The nuances” - Quill interacts and looks at you. She is aware that you are there and that gives her a convincing sense of realism.

• The puzzles in the game are not related to intellect but instead rely on becoming familiar with the environment and how the pieces of the environment interact with each other.

• Loved that it was built around a storybook that you could read as you went. It’s very reminiscent of the Never Ending Story.

• It was just, and I quote, "awesome cool."

CONS

• It would be nice if Quill was able to offer better hints to help with puzzles and battles; not enough to give things away but to be more interactive in finding solutions. Sometimes you feel completely responsible for Quill and it would be better to have more of a balanced partnership.

• Emotionally you can feel “left out” in the sense of either being solely responsible for Quill or feeling as if there isn’t that much you can do during gameplay. For instance: if you interact with some of the monsters, the monster don’t seem to be aware of your presence and yet in other situations you are the only one who can hold the monsters at bay. 

• Because of the realism of the game, Quill dying can cause emotional responses, especially for younger players. For example, my mom’s game glitched and instead of Quill fighting the monsters, it looked like she was trying to hide against you (The Reader) for help. While this was obviously not as intended, Quill’s realism and glitches that could cause inferred emotional responses could be upsetting for younger players if Quill ends up dying.

• However, the negatives are so minor they are almost inconsequential and didn’t affect gameplay. 

My mom, who had never played a VR game before, completed Moss in about 8 hours over a few days. It can be played sitting down, and it offers beautiful, realistic graphics, an enchanting storyline, and an adorable main character that you accompany through gameplay.

She is very excited about Book 2.

Let me forget about the fact this is VR for a second and just talk about the game directly. The story is cute, the basic plot seems borrowed from Never Ending Story: you are the reader of a magic book and you help the characters in it overcome their obstacles. This plot works better in a movie because the viewer is not putting itself in the shoes of the character who is reading the book, but in the videogame, the player is the reader and that just sounds weird. Maybe the game should have acknowledged me as the gamer already. The game starts with you looking at a book and flipping its pages and you'll go back to this scene several times during the game. The actual game is really cool though, it's a regular 3D platformer with "static" cameras (as static as it can be in VR) and you move from "room to room" (not literal rooms, but almost like pages in an illustrated book), solving puzzles and jumping on platforms. Then you get back to the book staring part for more story exposition, and that it's so boring compared to the rest of the game that I sigh in frustration every time it happens in the game.

There are some glaring interface problems here. I felt I was off center in the world and I wanted to reset my view for the game so I pressed the oculus menu and it glitched the hell out. So I thought maybe the game has the option. It does not have any VR settings at all. So I figured I'll just save, close and open the game.  I opened up the menu to save the game. There was the option there "save". You click on it and another menu pops up with some slots. If you click the one already filled you might think it will replace the old save but it asks if you want to load that. Well, no, I thought I was in the save menu. An outstanding gaming experience and a must have for VR in my opinion. The developers thought outside the box and it shows. Essentially, the game is a mix of puzzles, platforming and action. This is a slower paced game you play seated, so it's great for relaxing in to, if you know what I mean. 

- Story 10/10. Could be deeper, but it fits just right for the length of the experience. And the story re-inforces the unique gameplay relationship you have with the main character.

- Length 6/10. Hey, I get it, indie game devs sweat blood to make these things, so they can't all be 50 hour epics. The funny thing about VR is that I feel my time is better spent. Like each hour counts for more. So, I spent 4+ hours, and in the end wanted it to be longer, but I'm still satisfied. 

My wish list:

- A sequal, obviously.

- More of an RPG progression, with a few poserups or better swords etc.

Overall, one of my favorite VR titles so far. Hope it comes to the Quest.

45093318.review:
Score: Good 3/5 
Pros: Beautiful and immersive, creative level design, fun puzzles
Cons: Mediocre story, lacks some polish in platforming, uninspiring sound track 


Moss is a platform puzzle adventurer which strongly benefits from being a VR title, as it makes use of the technology to build immersive and beautiful set pieces. It has some cleverly designed levels which call for smart interactions of the VR controllers. It is certainly a joy to play through. However, it is held back by a less than persuasive story, some minor bugs along the way, and a forgettable sound track.
 
We are introduced to the game while turning the pages of a book which tells a tale of woe in the land of Moss. While recounting the backstory we come across our protagonist, Quill. We are told that a bond between the player and Quill is created. The plot left a lot to be desired, along with the characters that had some questionable lines. But as far as I was concerned, that was all the justification I needed in order to enjoy the amazing experience of seeing a game come to life right in front of me! This was my first experience playing a 3rd person game in VR and I am so excited about the new prospects this point of view opens up for VR. Everything about this game in VR made it look and feel great. From a quaint village in the forest, to the ruins of grand hallways, the attention to detail when it came to the environment can be greatly appreciated. Lighting, suitable sound effects and beautifully rendered textures all lend to a wonderfully immersive experience. Running Quill through each level, solving puzzles and fighting enemies felt like she was an actual action figure that had come to life. 


While Moss could be titled as a platformer, and it does a good enough job, it isn’t its strongest suit. Some areas which require jumping can be frustrating, as not being lined up exactly as you should leads to some your death. Miss a ledge ever so slightly and Quill will hurtle down with not so much as a falling animation. It’s not that it is difficult to line up and time jumps in 3D, it’s just that Quill doesn’t feel as responsive and smooth as she should for a platformer. In some areas I managed to run off a ledge but jumped anyway and was surprised to see Quill respond, jumping as if she wasn’t in free fall. Also, I found that after landing a jump and with my thumb still pressing forward, Quill would not continue moving and force to let go and press forward again. While they weren't game breaking issues, the finicky controls became much more apparent towards the end of the game, when it demanded well-timed and accurate platforming.  


This game instead shines with its interactive and rewarding puzzles. While Quill needs to get from A to B, you as the player may need to interact with the environment. Perhaps being required to pull a lever, or move a platform up. This involvement added another dimension to the game. The game builds on this by also adding other layers to puzzles such as manipulating enemies and making sure Quill is in the right place. Throw in some more enemies that are actively trying to kill you and it suddenly becomes challenging and a blast to play. The puzzles were never too vague, and I did feel satisfied when I overcame them. Being required to actively interact may have contributed to a deeper sense of achievement and self-satisfaction. I also appreciated the collectibles in the game. In each scene there are hidden scrolls which, once collected, add a piece to a mosaic. While some are in plain sight, others are more well-hidden and may require a second run through to find them all. Unlike other games, where collectibles progress is hidden in menus, you get to see the artwork after each chapter. The collectibles offer a fun treasure hunt and some incentive to play again.


Combat in the game is a welcome addition. Moss isn’t a hack and slash game by any means, so I wasn’t expecting to smash the controller as I usually do, but the lack of different attack moves and combos was felt. It would have been impressive to have seen different weapon types, and armour upgrades. A lack of an in-game HUD showing your vitals was also missing, instead you are warned of Quills closeness to death by a heartbeat sound. There were no bosses except for the final one hopefully we can see more bosses and other improvements to combat in a sequel that may happen as they would a lot of character to the game.



Moss is one of those few VR titles that feels like a full game and isn't in early access. It included a bit of everything from platforming, fighting, collectibles, puzzles, story, and player interaction. You definitely get your money’s worth with this title. While some of these elements weren’t exactly perfect, they were still decent enough that you could enjoy the game. Especially, when you can appreciate this fantastic immersive world in VR that has been superbly designed. Considering that the VR gaming market is still in its early stages, this game opens the realms of possibilities for so many other titles. Hopefully we can see more 3rd person perspective titles in VR. Personally, I can’t wait till we see a ‘Little Nightmares’ or ‘Inside’, but a fighting game would equally be welcome. Be sure to share what games you would like to see in this perspective in the comments below!

43921338.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Moss is a 3D platformer with action and puzzle elements, designed for, and only playable in, Virtual Reality.

In Moss you play Quill, an energetic field mouse who's rather fast on her feet and handy with a sword. One day Quill finds a magical glass that summons a "Reader", a much larger being with the ability to control the world around Quill. You also play the Reader.

Guiding Quill home, you meet Uncle Argus, an old mouse warrior, who is surprised and scared when she reveals you. He tells her that the magical glass that summoned you is very dangerous. Setting off into the night with nary a word, Uncle Argus only tells Quill that she can't leave the house until he returns.

As if she's going to listen to that ... .

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
I was a little disappointed with Moss to begin with. The game started in a sort of church-like building, with a book on a stand waiting for me to read it. Using the controllers I reached out and turned the page, and the story began, with a voice actor introducing the background of the world. It was all a bit ho-hum.

Once the introduction was finished, though, I found myself floating in the beautiful, lush forest of the Clearing, watching Quill as she foraged about and uncovered her magical treasure. Then she looked up and saw me, and waited for me to do something, and I looked down and saw myself reflected in the gently flowing stream. It was at this point that I realised that this was the best-looking VR game I'd played. Screenshots don't do it justice.

While the game is made up of a number of somewhat-disconnected screens, the world they create is wonderfully realised. So much detail has gone into each area, I still find myself simply wanting to look around and watch the world go by -- something which makes the lack of manual save points even more frustrating. Quill and the other mice in her community look simply amazing, with detailed models, beautiful textures, and realistic, but also fantastic animations. The game perfectly presents the feeling of watching a living, breathing world inhabited by tiny creatures.

Music, too, is wonderful, and sound effects are vibrant and suit the game perfectly. Voice work is limited to the book-reading sections between each major area change, and I have to say that the voice actor didn't do a great job. While the feeling of someone reading a children's book was well realised, I found the voices annoying enough that I wanted to skip through these sections quickly, for the most part.

Performance was fine on my GTX1070-based gaming laptop.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Moss is essentially a 3D action platformer with some basic puzzles, most of which are related to moving or rotating special glowing platforms. You play both the protagonist, Quill, and the Reader, yourself, and I thought this dichotomy ruined the otherwise fantastic sense of immersion that the game provides. I would have been much happier with more to do as the Reader, indirectly signalling for Quill to proceed, rather than having direct control over her. I also think that would have removed some of the game's frustrations.

The game is fairly short. I've taken my time with it, mainly because of control issues, but I've seen others have completed it in a handful of hours. It's made up of a number of small set-piece style levels or screens, each of which typically has a platforming puzzle to solve, enemies to kill, or both. Puzzles tend to be mostly the same -- drag this or rotate that -- while also controlling Quill in typical third-person platformer fashion, and combat is fairly repetitive, though the use of the Reader's glowy hand powers to help is a nice touch. There's a reasonable sense of progression as your make your way through the game, but after the first couple of hours I found it a bit of a hard slog, fighting more with the game itself than Quill's enemies.

Beyond some occasional technical weirdness, the game's limitations become evident after only a relatively short time. First, there are no manual saves; it's all checkpoint-based. If you want to go back and try to get a scroll or even just look at the pretty graphics a couple of screens before your current location, generally it's just bad luck. You can't! You can only restart each 'chapter' or resume from your previous position. Some of the puzzles aren't great, either. On one screen shortly after the first boss I found myself trying to jump onto a ledge that was right in front of me. Quill could jump on one right next to it fine because it had the 'magic' scratchy-looking texture, but not this one, even though it was the exact same height, distance, etc. It ruined the immersion a bit; there's no logical reason why she could only jump on the ledge the developers chose and not the one that I did.

Controls are wonky, too, and were the main reason I still haven't finished the game. I thought it was my hacked-together VR rig -- and I'm still convinced it's much harder than it should be because of this -- but seeing reviews from HTC Vive owners, I suspect there are actually problems with the core control scheme, too. Quill will sometimes move of her own accord, and camera angles, while changeable by looking around, do also tend to make jumps a bit hard to judge. I also found Quill's inertia and friction a bit off; why is the ground so slippery!?

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
Pros:
+ Wonderful immersion and interaction with Quill
+ Beautiful world and characters
+ Steam VR Collectible

Cons:
- Weird dual-control ideas
- Long load times
- Checkpoint saves
- Some nonsensical restrictions
- Expensive

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Let me say straight up that Moss is the most impressive looking VR game I've played so far. It's worth checking out simply because of that.

Okay, now that's out of the way, let me tell you why I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would.

Moss is a perfect example of style over substance. It's short and its gameplay, while interesting because of the interface, is actually fairly simplistic, even bland in places. The game's premise is immersion: it draws you in right from the start, when Quill looks at you with wonder, and you glance down and see yourself -- a floating mask -- reflected in a stream. But then it takes that sense of immersion and shatters it. Why am I controlling Quill AND myself? I kept wondering. Here are my glowing hand-thingies, which I can move around to change Quill's world and allow her to progress, but why, then, do I also control her? For me the wonderful sense of immersion that the game produced was all but destroyed by this. Why is Quill prompting me for a high five after solving a puzzle when I both controlled the world and her to do it? The realisation that I was giving myself a high-five was too much.

But the game looks and feels SO darn good. The set pieces are phenomenal, like a sprawling fantasy doll's house come to life. Quill is amazing, too; her animations and reactions are so lifelike.

So I heartily recommend Moss as a VR experience. As a game, well, if you like 3D platformers and you don't mind fiddly controls and nonsensical platforming restrictions then it's probably worth a look from that point of view, too. Just bear in mind that it is very short for the price.

[h1]Save for Later[/h1]

Note: I played this game on an Android phone using VRidge / Riftcat, with emulated Vive tracked motion controls.

43198934.review:
First, a couple of things that will make the game much better for you:

1) If you are using a Vive, use the stick of an Xbox or similar joypad in your left hand, and a Vive controller in your right hand. This allows you more precise directional control, and you will need it! The Vive trackpads are simply abysmal at this. (Thankfully, Valve seem to realise this and are adding joysticks to the Knuckles controllers.) You can play the whole game and all required actions this way, using the right hand Vive controller for grabbing things as well as the jump and attack buttons (which work fine via the trackpad).

2) After loading the game, go into the in-game Settings menu and change the graphics quality. It defaults to Low, even on a 1080ti, which is jaggy city. Worked great on High for me, but YMMV. Game engine ignores the supersampling setting in SteamVR so don't bother with that.

Now the review:

I usually ignore sit-down VR games as I feel they miss half the point of VR, but I gave this one a chance and it was definitely worth it. You are sat down, but you'll be reaching into the scene to manipulate objects and enemies, and you'll be leaning and bending around to find hidden secrets in the world or peer through windows, like looking into a doll's house where you control one of the characters. The diorama style graphics work really, really well in VR and it is quite an experience in places. Sometimes I had to stand up to get an eagle-eye view of the scene and see if anything was hidden high up. It's a traditional side-on 3D platformer in a way, but it really uses VR as well.

A really charming game, not too challenging but not trivially easy either. I died in quite a few places, and occasionally wasn't sure what to do, but I always progressed after thinking about things for a few minutes, and never had to look up a solution. Total playtime was 5.4 hours, and most of that was my first playthrough; I then used chapter select to find the 5 or so collectibles I was missing, which maybe counted for 30-60 minutes of that time. (Far as I can tell, collectibles don't do anything except fill in some objects in the intermission area, so they're totally optional, but I like collecting hidden stuff, and only missed a few. The game tells you which chapters the missing things are in and lets you jump to a chapter.) Pretty good length for a VR game, and a decent price given VR remains a risky, niche market and this is a really charming, polished game, with great graphics and animations, a nice story, and well done gameplay.

For those unsure what kind of game it is, each area is a stationary scene that you sit in front of. You control a little mouse directly using directional input, with jump and attack buttons. You can also reach into the scene to move things around and manipulate objects and enemies. You have to solve platforming puzzles and sometimes some combat to get through each scene, at which point it fades out and the next scene fades in. (You can usually look left or right to see the adjacent scenes; the fading is just so you don't have to keep moving around in the real world, really.)

It's quite a traditional game in some ways, but uses VR really well at the same time. It's nice to see something really shine in VR that isn't just another wave shooter.

If there is a sequel, I'll buy it on release day for sure. Can't say better than that really.

[b]Moss[/b], a timed PSVR exclusive, is finally available on PC for both Oculus Rift and HTC Vive. Scroll to the bottom to see if it is worth getting. 

[h1]Story [/h1]
The story follows a brave little mouse Quill. She finds an ancient “glass relic” while exploring the woods near her village. Quill takes her finding back home to ask her old uncle if he knows anything about it.  He tells Quill that magic powers have awoken and that she is in grave danger now. The rest you will learn throughout the game. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]	
Moss is a seated VR experience. The game is presented as a storybook that is being read to you by a narrator. You are being addressed as [i]a reader[/i]. Although you are not the main character you are still a part of the story. In [b]Moss[/b] you play as yourself and you also have a direct control over Quill. 

The game largely plays as a 3rd person action-platformer. Quill can jump, climb and fight enemies with a tiny sword. As [i]a reader[/i] your hands are being represented by glowing orbs. You help Quill to solve puzzles, clear paths by moving blocks and interacting with different mechanisms that are too large for Quill. You can also heal Quill if she gets injured.

Both of you form a solid team. Quill will always point you in the right direction if you don’t know what to do. She even high fives you when you get the solution right! 

[b]Moss[/b] is a linear game split into multiple chapters that can be replayed at any time. Each chapter has a number of hidden collectibles (“relic dust” and “forgotten fragments”). These collectibles are purely optional but it provides a fun additional challenge and a reason to revisit the game. 

[h1]Visuals and Sound [/h1]
The game’s magical world is very beautiful. Quill feels alive, her movements are very smooth. Since every scene is concentrated right in front of the player, Polyarc was able to achieve the level of polish that many current gen VR games are lacking. It really is like being inside a fairy tale. 
Sound effects and music are great. The narration is also done very well. 

[h1]Performance[/h1]
The game is well optimized and runs great. I did not experience any technical issues whatsoever. 
[i]For Oculus Rift users:[/i] Steam version uses Oculus SDK and should be identical to an Oculus Store version. There is a native Touch support. Steam VR does not need to be running.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
[b]Moss[/b] is a carefully crafted game with beautiful graphics and a heartwarming story. Both combat and puzzles offer a decent challenge but are never too difficult or frustrating. It is a very unique VR experience and a great game overall. This is an easy recommendation for me.
The sequel is already in the works. I hope it will be even bigger and better. I cannot wait!

So the last achievement I got for this game is called "A Promising Beginning"

That is absolutely my assessment of the game. Promising, but only a beginning.

To give the game it's due, it is a fantastic concept and it pushes boundaries of how we can think about VR games and what we can do with them. The first time I was truly in the world, seeing my reflection in the water, Quill looking up at me, feeling the world all around me I genuinely cried from the beauty and the wonder of all of it.

Here's the bad: the controls drove me up the wall, the story is incomplete to the point of feeling incredibly frustrating and frankly the game is lacking a lot of polish. One example: in the middle of solving a puzzle Quill paused to ask for a high-five, however as this puzzle required timed jumping, the fact that she stopped meant we had to reset the puzzle and solve it again in order to actually complete the damn thing. 

Another big problem is the way you control Quill means you're going to miss about half of the jumps you attempt, which normally results in either dying or an amount of rework that is almost as frustrating. This specific problem rips any sense of immersion to shreds, and I partly think the only reason you have this kind of direct control over Quill is because the devs didn't want to take the risk of having the player completely hands-off with her. I do think the game could have done amazingly if the gameplay was about plotting out a route for Quill and having her do her best to follow your directions. Combat could have been handled by a combination of painting targets for her to strike and controlling the battlefield directly through manipulating the environment and enemies. Instead I got to watch my precious girl jump to her death time and again because there's just no good way to control someone from a second person perspective.

I really do think this is a promising beginning, I really love the way they creators are telling their story and I love my poor uncoordinated mouse-child with all my heart, but damn does she have a way to go before I start recommending this game the way I wish I could.

While I've had a few experiences with VR at this point, some good, some having potential but lacking in their execution, and some simply bad, Quill was probably the first game in VR I'd outright call great. I won't deny that I have some reservations, and it's hardly flawless, but overall I walked away from the game feeling mostly satisfied with the adventure.

While you control an adorable mouse protagonist called Quill through level after level in a fantasy world, I wouldn't call Quill the player character. The 'hook' of Moss is that you, the player, are a seperate entity in the world, guiding Quill and helping her with simple controls by interacting with the world around her by grabbing, lifting, moving and generally just manipulating specific objects. Each new level is like a beautiful charming little diorama, with enemies, platforming and puzzles to overcome. 

The player is, however, limited in what they can do. A few more details and options in how the player interacts with the world would have been welcome. It's understandable why they designed it the way they did, though, ensuring that it doesn't become too complex to develop. At one point I thought they introduced an interesting mechanic where the player had to light the way in complete darkness... but it's never actually realized and goes away almost as quickly as it's introduced.

The game is quite forgiving, having frequent checkpoints and allowing the player to heal Quill in just a few seconds. There might be one or two moments where you need to multitask, keeping Quill out of harms way while having to look the other way, but being difficult hardly seems like a goal of the game. It just wants to be an approachable fun adventure, and it mostly nails this.

It's a fun adventure that's definitely worth your time, but that said, I do have some gripes.

The biggest problem to me, and the one I'll focus on here, is the fact that parts of the story falls flat in my eyes. While Quill is adorable and very likable, other characters don't get a lot of time to be more than archetypes. I kind of struggle to think of why some of them even existed.

The good people at Polyarc Games have decided to tell the story in the way of you, the player, reading about Quill's adventure in a book. I like this approach on a practical level, allowing some scenes to have a better focus on important exposition without being too demanding for developers and animators, but I can't help but to feel it could have been better implemented to tell a more invovled story. 

The whole adventure is narrated by a single voice actress. While the voice actress in question is clearly talented and even has some range, I personally dislike a narration of this type. That's very subjective, of course, so feel free to ignore me about this.

I still really like the charming tiny fantasy world they've created here. It's not original a bit of the time, but it's implemented well with a slew of little details. I could really see a sequel take this to new heights, fleshing out the world and adding even more character (and actual characters) to this world of Moss.

I once learned that while traditional media should generally go for "Show, don't tell", games should instead go for "Do, don't show". There's a segment late in the game that, due to the choice of telling the story through a storybook, falls kind of flat. It's supposed to be a important, resonating emotional moment between the player and Quill that allows her to grow as a character, but it feels weaker than it should be. Instead of *Doing* it through an in-game interaction such as cheering up a distraught little mouse with a friendly gesture, or *Showing* it through a series of emotional animations depicting her weakest moment and subsequent triumphant determination, we are instead practically treated to a still and narration *Telling* us "I'm sad. But you're here. I'm all better now!" in a very brief timespan... That whole sequence, both immediately before and after, could have been realized beautifully in gameplay without so much as a word spoken.

Also, as a last note, this game doesn't really end as it just awkwarldy... stops. It doesn't even end on a real cliffhanger, it's just... "to be continued in part 2". This frustrated me immensly. It would have been better standing on its own. They literally only needed to cut out 10 or so seconds of dialogue and it would ironically have made me *more* excited for a sequel.

The story was over! Quill started out small but then rose to greatness, she had grown as a character which we knew by how it was both *Shown* AND *Done* in the exciting moments before the ending! Tiny mouse did big things! She had reached her goal! STORY OVER! I wanted them to end it, and maybe pleasantly surprise us with a sequel later! Instead, by having the ending feel like it should drag on (but doesn't), it's like Quill's growth suddenly got stunted. It made me frustrated impressively fast.

That sounds worse than it actually is. This is a great game, deserving of your time, and I hope other good developers start getting inspired so we get more excellent adventures in VR like this.

Quill is absolutely adorable and I still want to see more of her adventures.

Recommended.

I don’t usually review games as a habit but I do make the occasional exception when a game is particularly good and really moves me...  So with that being said here is my amateur review of Moss…
 
WOW WOW WOW!  I cannot say enough about this game. It is engaging, unique, captivating and charming all rolled up into an adventure that stands out like nothing else I have ever played in VR.  You are basically living in a story book, controlling the main protagonist – Quill.  Making him run, jump and fight enemies all to save his uncle from the evil that lurks in the shadows.

The gameplay is amazing but what is even more amazing is how this all is presented to you.  VR makes the environments come to life before your very eyes.  You look down upon the land of Moss while controlling Quill and interacting with the environment before you, helping your little friend move through her quest to fight the evil that has captured her uncle. 
Each time Quill would overcome a puzzle or best her enemies or both, you and her will move to the next scene.  With each new scene presented I found myself more and more amazed at how beautiful the environments are. This is truly a delight and a place that I did not want to leave. 
 
To me, Moss is by far the best game I have ever played in VR.  I was continually drawn into the world of Moss as each new chapter unfolded before my eyes.  The puzzles while somewhat simple were to me-a joy to overcome.  I tend to get bored with frustration if things get too difficult.   However I really feel that they struck the perfect balance between simplicity and fun for the world before me.
 
I do read others reviews about the controls being too difficult or not accurate enough, and I can tell you with complete honesty that in the beginning I had a bit of trouble controlling Quill with enough precision to complete a few scroll challenges in some tougher areas, or not to die by fighting enemies that I could have beaten with my eyes closed if I had a proper button and joystick gamepad setup.  However, by the time I was a few hours into my quest, I was running and jumping and slashing my foes with ease.  I could tell I was getting better at controlling Quill and interacting with my environment, and by the end of the game I had mastered the controls and they just felt great.
  
I think what intrigues me most about Moss, is the possibilities it has opened my mind to.  When I was young, my friends and I would sit around the table in my basement and play D&D for hours on end.  Slaying dragons and besting foes of all sorts while we leveled our character’s and role-played till our hearts were content. At that moment we were living in the world that our DM had created for us.  Much like how I was living in the world that Polyarc had created.   After playing Moss and experiencing how the developers transformed the adventure genre into a living breathing world right before my eyes, my only hope is to be able to experience a full on multiplayer RPG in the Moss vein as well.  This would truly be something special. 

In closing, after 10 hours of game play (yes it took me that long) I am now ready for my next adventure with Quill... If only Quill was ready for me...

Game completed update:

I cannot recommend this game, both for the $30 price tag (current play time is 95% completion, it's a neat experience, but there's not much to it in the end), and because the controls make the game infuriating.

For some reason, your movement will randomly be a walk instead of a run, which will make 100% of jumps fail, or you to get hit by monsters.  This is normally only slightly annoying, but the further you get into the game, the more time this costs you, more and more, to the point of infuriation, which detracts from the game.  They also, at the end, start giving you blind failures, which, combined with the long respawn times (5-10 seconds from the point you fucked up to gaining control of your character again) just leads to abject murder of the game experience.

As this is a platformer at base, it lives and dies by its controls, and the floaty nature, combined with the above problem, and the fact you can just run off ledges, and a complete lack of movement assisting, was already digging the game's grave about have way in, and used a bulldozer to bury it at the end.

I would love to recommend this on Quill alone, because the animation and semi awareness of the player is very endearing, but it cannot charge $30 for unrefined controls and a dearth of content.

Also, anyone that's asking for this to come to not-VR:  Keep doing it.  There's some naysayers about how such a request will never make non-VR happy, but there's nothing in this game that distinctly requires VR in such a way that removing it and making it snap-to action controls wouldn't be just as effective.  The game would map to an SNES controller without issue (you'd want the analog sticks, but still).


====Original ===== 
This early in, it's hard to gather that there's anything fundamentally special about it as a game.  It has, thus far, utilized VR very minimally (in the kind of way that people asking for this to exist without VR are justified), but there's nothing wrong with it.  It's not a selling point for VR, but it isn't really gimmicky, either.  I'd buy it if you have a VR, otherwise you're not going to be inclined to get into VR because of this.

The main character is adorable, but it's hard to appreciate it, sometimes, with how far away the view is by default.

I also don't understand the design ethos behind fading to black to respawn the character, it's very jarring in VR (not in a shock sense, but it diminishes the experience), as well as loading between zones.  There should be optimization around loading to make it as seemless as possible, but it seems like it wasn't taken into consideration beyond how consoles/other games have it happen.

Thus far, I'd recommend it, but I actually wish the game was an escort quest.  The platforming controls are floaty because of touchpad instead of press-to-move (I have not liked this is any game I've had it in), and not extremely rewarding.  If the game was about guiding the protagonist and assisting them, instead of directly controlling them, I think the experience would be far and away better.
